text: houston mayor others help residents after deadly blast houstons mayor and others say they will work to provide assistance to residents whose homes were damaged after a massive explosion at a warehouse that killed two workers and injured 20 others
source: {\id\": \"thetorontostar--2020-01-26--Houston mayor
source_type: others help residents after deadly blast\"
column9: others help residents after deadly blast\"
column10: \"content\": \"Houston\\u2019s mayor and others say they will work to provide assistance to residents whose homes were damaged after a massive explosion at a warehouse that killed two workers and injured 20 others.\\n\\nMayor Sylvester Turner on Saturday walked through the impacted neighbourhoods in northwest Houston and spoke with residents who were cleaning up after Friday\\u2019s explosion. Cleanup and repair efforts continued Sunday.\\n\\n\\u201cThese people\\u2019s lives have been devastated by the Houston explosion. We are not going to forget about them
column11: \\u201d Turner said.\\n\\nThe explosion happened about 4:30 a.m. Friday inside a building at Watson Grinding and Manufacturing
column12: which makes valves and provides thermal-spray coatings for equipment in various industries
column13: authorities said. Employees Frank Flores and Gerardo Castorena were killed.\\n\\nIn a statement released Saturday
column14: Castorena\\u2019s family said
column15: \\u201cIt\\u2019s with a heavy heart that we had to say goodbye to a loving father
column17: brother
column18: and friend yesterday morning. We do ask for privacy as we grieve during this time. Thank you all to those for your kind words and support as we get through this difficult time.\\u201d\\n\\nAuthorities say an additional 20 people were injured \\u2014 two other warehouse workers and 18 others from neighbouring homes and businesses. The explosion\\u2019s cause is being investigated.\\n\\nMore than 200 homes in surrounding neighbourhoods were damaged as the force of the blast shattered windows
column19: knocked down ceilings
column20: bent garage doors and moved some homes off their foundations.\\n\\nDozens of volunteers were out helping residents on Saturday.\\n\\nMore than 80 of the volunteers were from Restore Houston
column21: a network of area churches dedicated to assisting families whose homes were damaged from flooding during Hurricane Harvey in 2017.\\n\\n\\u201cWe\\u2019ll be doing some work on homes
column22: boarding up windows
column24: but more importantly we\\u2019ll be loving on our neighbours and making sure they are aware that they are not alone in this
column25: \\u201d Josef Klam
column26: a pastor with Chapelwood United Methodist Church
column27: told the Houston Chronicle.\\n\\nGet more of the Star in your inbox Never miss the latest news from the Star. Sign up for our newsletters to get today's top stories
column28: your favourite columnists and lots more in your inbox Sign Up Now\"

column9: others help residents after deadly blast\"
column10: \"content\": \"Houston\\u2019s mayor and others say they will work to provide assistance to residents whose homes were damaged after a massive explosion at a warehouse that killed two workers and injured 20 others.\\n\\nMayor Sylvester Turner on Saturday walked through the impacted neighbourhoods in northwest Houston and spoke with residents who were cleaning up after Friday\\u2019s explosion. Cleanup and repair efforts continued Sunday.\\n\\n\\u201cThese people\\u2019s lives have been devastated by the Houston explosion. We are not going to forget about them
column11: \\u201d Turner said.\\n\\nThe explosion happened about 4:30 a.m. Friday inside a building at Watson Grinding and Manufacturing
column12: which makes valves and provides thermal-spray coatings for equipment in various industries
column13: authorities said. Employees Frank Flores and Gerardo Castorena were killed.\\n\\nIn a statement released Saturday
column14: Castorena\\u2019s family said
column15: \\u201cIt\\u2019s with a heavy heart that we had to say goodbye to a loving father
column17: brother
column18: and friend yesterday morning. We do ask for privacy as we grieve during this time. Thank you all to those for your kind words and support as we get through this difficult time.\\u201d\\n\\nAuthorities say an additional 20 people were injured \\u2014 two other warehouse workers and 18 others from neighbouring homes and businesses. The explosion\\u2019s cause is being investigated.\\n\\nMore than 200 homes in surrounding neighbourhoods were damaged as the force of the blast shattered windows
column19: knocked down ceilings
column20: bent garage doors and moved some homes off their foundations.\\n\\nDozens of volunteers were out helping residents on Saturday.\\n\\nMore than 80 of the volunteers were from Restore Houston
column21: a network of area churches dedicated to assisting families whose homes were damaged from flooding during Hurricane Harvey in 2017.\\n\\n\\u201cWe\\u2019ll be doing some work on homes
column22: boarding up windows
column24: but more importantly we\\u2019ll be loving on our neighbours and making sure they are aware that they are not alone in this
column25: \\u201d Josef Klam
column26: a pastor with Chapelwood United Methodist Church
column27: told the Houston Chronicle.\\n\\nGet more of the Star in your inbox Never miss the latest news from the Star. Sign up for our newsletters to get today's top stories

column9: others help residents after deadly blast\"
column10: \"content\": \"Houston\\u2019s mayor and others say they will work to provide assistance to residents whose homes were damaged after a massive explosion at a warehouse that killed two workers and injured 20 others.\\n\\nMayor Sylvester Turner on Saturday walked through the impacted neighborhoods in northwest Houston and spoke with residents who were cleaning up after Friday\\u2019s explosion. Cleanup and repair efforts continued Sunday.\\n\\n\\u201cThese people\\u2019s lives have been devastated by the Houston explosion. We are not going to forget about them
column11: \\u201d Turner said.\\n\\nThe explosion happened about 4:30 a.m. Friday inside a building at Watson Grinding and Manufacturing
column12: which makes valves and provides thermal-spray coatings for equipment in various industries
column13: authorities said. Employees Frank Flores and Gerardo Castorena were killed.\\n\\nIn a statement released Saturday
column14: Castorena\\u2019s family said
column15: \\\"It's with a heavy heart that we had to say goodbye to a loving father
column17: brother
column18: and friend yesterday morning. We do ask for privacy as we grieve during this time. Thank you all to those for your kind words and support as we get through this difficult time.\\u201d\\n\\nAuthorities say an additional 20 people were injured \\u2014 two other warehouse workers and 18 others from neighboring homes and businesses. The explosion\\u2019s cause is being investigated.\\n\\nMore than 200 homes in surrounding neighborhoods were damaged as the force of the blast shattered windows
column19: knocked down ceilings
column20: bent garage doors and moved some homes off their foundations.\\n\\nDozens of volunteers were out helping residents on Saturday.\\n\\nMore than 80 of the volunteers were from Restore Houston
column21: a network of area churches dedicated to assisting families whose homes were damaged from flooding during Hurricane Harvey in 2017.\\n\\n\\u201cWe\\u2019ll be doing some work on homes
column22: boarding up windows
column24: but more importantly we\\u2019ll be loving on our neighbors and making sure they are aware that they are not alone in this
column25: \\u201d Josef Klam
column26: a pastor with Chapelwood United Methodist Church
column27: told the Houston Chronicle.\"

text: the guardian view on holocaust memorial day as necessary as ever  editorial four years after the liberation of the largest nazi extermination camp on 27 january 1945 the german philosopher theodor adorno observed to write poetry after auschwitz is barbaric
source: {\id\": \"theguardianuk--2020-01-26--The Guardian view on Holocaust Memorial Day: as necessary as ever | Editorial\"
column7: \"title\": \"The Guardian view on Holocaust Memorial Day: as necessary as ever | Editorial\"
column8: \"content\": \"Four years after the liberation of the largest Nazi extermination camp
column9: on 27 January 1945
column10: the German philosopher Theodor Adorno observed: \\u201cTo write poetry after Auschwitz is barbaric.\\u201d He came to revise that view
column11: along with its implication that a kind of silence was perhaps the only possible response to the horror of the Holocaust. Later
column12: he wrote that \\u201cperennial suffering has as much right to expression as a tortured man to scream\\u201d.\\n\\nSurvivor testimony has always been crucial in keeping alive the memory of a unique episode of human depravity. The courage and mental fortitude of those who have borne witness to the industrialised murder of 6 million Jews has played a vital role in helping inoculate European societies against the virus of antisemitism. But that era of witness is coming to an end. During the last five years
column13: almost half the remaining survivors have passed away. On Monday
column14: some 120 Holocaust survivors from around the world will attend a ceremony to commemorate the 75th anniversary of the Red Army\\u2019s arrival at the gates of Auschwitz; it is likely to be the last gathering of its kind at a significant anniversary.\\n\\nBut the need to remember and retain the lessons of what became the Holocaust \\u2013 from its insidious and incremental beginnings in 1930s Germany to the mass factories of death that began their infernal activities in 1941 \\u2013 grows rather than diminishes. As the experience of the death camps begins to fade from living memory
column15: there are signs that
column16: in a period of resurgent nationalism and xenophobia
column17: postwar taboos are losing some of their force and historical revisionism is being deployed to buttress senses of national self-esteem. In the eastern German state of Thuringia
column18: the nationalist Alternative f\\u00fcr Deutschland (AfD) party recently outperformed the centre-right Christian Democrats in elections
column19: under the regional leadership of Bj\\u00f6rn H\\u00f6cke. Mr H\\u00f6cke has in the past railed at the construction of \\u201cmonuments of shame\\u201d such as the Holocaust memorial in Berlin. He has said: \\u201cThis laughable policy [in Germany] of coming to terms with the past is crippling us.\\u201d\\n\\nIn Poland
column20: the Law and Justice party passed a law making it illegal to accuse the Polish nation of complicity in the Holocaust. The government has since watered down the legislation
column21: abandoning the notion of criminal penalties for violators. But one prominent Polish-American Holocaust scholar was questioned under the law
column22: although the case was dropped last year.\\n\\nIn Hungary
column24: Viktor Orb\\u00e1n
column25: has pursued a prolonged dog-whistle campaign against the Jewish philanthropist George Soros
column26: whose arguments in favour of accepting Muslim migrants from the Middle East have been presented as \\u201cendangering the Christian culture of Europe\\u201d. Meanwhile
column27: in the UK
column28: the Labour party\\u2019s failure to effectively combat the use of antisemitic tropes by some members led to a breakdown in its relations with the Jewish community.\\n\\nA defensive
column29: ethnocentric nationalism which views minorities with suspicion is one of the signs of post-crash times in Europe. Reports of antisemitic incidents are on the rise and political language distinguishing between those who \\u201cbelong\\u201d to the nation and those who do not has become more commonplace. The simultaneous rise of social media has also chipped steadily away at taboos which once set the parameters of acceptable public discourse. There is a pressing need for renewed vigilance
column30: with respect not only to antisemitism but also Islamophobia.\\n\\nThis Holocaust Memorial Day
column31: and the ceremony that will take place in Poland
column32: carry a special poignancy because of the diminishing number of survivors and the landmark nature of the date. Over the last 75 years
column33: survivors have talked in schools and on university campuses; inside museums and at parliaments. These were talks that were often difficult to deliver but which were undertaken out of a sense to duty to both the dead and the living; they helped keep the fire of conscience burning in Europe\\u2019s soul. A single human story
column34: told face to face
column35: conveys the tragedy of millions in a way that a recitation of figures never could. But the baton must be passed on and accepted. The Spanish philosopher George Santayana said of the Holocaust: \\u201cHe who does not learn from history is doomed to repeat it.\\u201d That lesson must never cease to be taught.\"
column37: \"url\": \"https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2020/jan/26/the-guardian-view-on-holocaust-memorial-day-as-necessary-as-ever\"
column38: \"published\": \"Sun
column40: \"published_utc\": 1580081784
column41: \"collection_utc\": 1580084658}"

Mr H\\u00f6cke has in the past railed at the construction of \\u201cmonuments of shame\\u201d such as the Holocaust memorial in Berlin. He has said: \\u201cThis laughable policy [in Germany] of coming to terms with the past is crippling us.\\u201d\\n\\nIn Poland
column20: the Law and Justice party passed a law making it illegal to accuse the Polish nation of complicity in the Holocaust. The government has since watered down the legislation
column21: abandoning the notion of criminal penalties for violators. But one prominent Polish-American Holocaust scholar was questioned under the law
column22: although the case was dropped last year.\\n\\nIn Hungary
column24: Viktor Orb\\u00e1n
column25: has pursued a prolonged dog-whistle campaign against the Jewish philanthropist George Soros
column26: whose arguments in favour of accepting Muslim migrants from the Middle East have been presented as \\u201cendangering the Christian culture of Europe\\u201d. Meanwhile
column27: in the UK
column28: the Labour party\\u2019s failure to effectively combat the use of antisemitic tropes by some members led to a breakdown in its relations with the Jewish community.\\n\\nA defensive
column29: ethnocentric nationalism which views minorities with suspicion is one of the signs of post-crash times in Europe. Reports of antisemitic incidents are on the rise and political language distinguishing between those who \\u201cbelong\\u201d to the nation and those who do not has become more commonplace. The simultaneous rise of social media has also chipped steadily away at taboos which once set the parameters of acceptable public discourse. There is a pressing need for renewed vigilance
column30: with respect not only to antisemitism but also Islamophobia.\\n\\nThis Holocaust Memorial Day
column31: and the ceremony that will take place in Poland
column32: carry a special poignancy because of the diminishing number of survivors and the landmark nature of the date. Over the last 75 years
column33: survivors have talked in schools and on university campuses; inside museums and at parliaments. These were talks that were often difficult to deliver but which were undertaken out of a sense to duty to both the dead and the living; they helped keep the fire of conscience burning in Europe\\u2019s soul. A single human story
column34: told face to face
column35: conveys the tragedy of millions in a way that a recitation of figures never could. But the baton must be passed on and accepted. The Spanish philosopher George Santayana said of the Holocaust: \\u201cHe who does not learn from history is doomed to repeat it.\\u201d That lesson must never cease to be taught.\"

column12: \"content\": \"NBA legend Kobe Bryant and his oldest daughter
column13: Gianna
column14: were killed in a fiery helicopter crash in California today.\\n\\nTMZ was the first to confirm that the 41-year-old and his daughter were on their way to the Mamba Academy for a basketball practice when the private helicopter went down at around 10 a.m. PST.\\n\\nThe website later reported that Gianna did not survive the crash. She was 13.\\n\\nOrange Coast College baseball coach John Altobelli
column15: his wife Kerry
column16: and their daughter Alyssa were also among the nine people killed in the crash
column17: officials said.\\n\\nAs news of the tragic accident emerged
column18: the sports world and beyond memorialized the basketball legend on Twitter.\\n\\nA \\\"shocked\\\" Michael Jordan lamented the passing of his \\\"little brother\\\" and the \\\"amazing dad.\\\"\\n\\nFormer teammate and Lakers star Shaquille O'Neal was \\\"sick\\\" and speechless over the loss of his \\\"niece\\\" and \\\"brother.\\\"\\n\\nFormer US President Barack Obama mourned the \\\"heartbreaking\\\" loss of the NBA great and his teenage daughter.\\n\\nBryant's helicopter took off from Long Beach at 8:29 a.m PST on Sunday
column19: then touched down again just eight minutes later in Orange County.\\n\\nIt is believed the stop was to pick up Bryant and the other passengers.\\n\\nThe helicopter then took off again 30 minutes later at 9:06 a.m. PST but never reached its final destination.\\n\\nThe helicopter spent around 12 minutes circling above Burbank
column20: California
column21: halfway through its flight
column22: before setting off on the fateful finally leg.\\n\\nExperienced LA helicopter pilot Phillipe Lesourd thinks this may have been to wait before getting clearance to continue their journey because of the bad weather.\\n\\nThe helicopter came down in what's been described as very foggy conditions
column24: which is home to many celebrities.\\n\\nIt's reported the helicopter crashed behind Kourtney Kardashian's home.\\n\\nLesourd talked to The Sun about the weather conditions.\\n\\nHe said: \\\"The visibility was so bad... The conditions were very
column25: very poor.\\n\\n\\\"I flew with my wife last week and there was fog inside the Malibu Canyon and we turned around because there was no visibility. Today would have been even worse.\\n\\n\\\"When there is no visibility
column26: when something happens you don't see the ground coming.\\\"\\n\\nThe experienced pilot continued to talk about the conditions in the last few days.\\n\\nHe said: \\\"Even last night there were no LAPD helicopters because of poor visibility.\\n\\n\\\"I checked the weather this morning around the time of the crash and it was low visibility everywhere in Los Angeles.\\n\\n\\\"If I fly above the fog and my engine quits
column27: or I have another problem and I have to land
column28: I cannot see and everybody dies. So when I was there I just turned around the fog.\\n\\n\\\"When you have one problem in a helicopter you have to fix it because the second problem is going to kill you.\\n\\n\\\"So when you have bad weather you don't push it because if something happens there's very little space to maneuver.\\n\\n\\\"I'm sure this pilot would have known that area. But he must have got surprised. And that type of helicopter can travel up to 115mph.\\\"\\n\\nThe Sun also listened to the dispatch call made after the crash.\\n\\nEmergency dispatchers could be heard saying: \\\"We do have one copter 300 yards east of this location. A chopper down. All units for assignment.\\\"\\n\\nReports of a \\\"small plane down with brush involved\\\" were the first indication of the tragedy in Calabasas.\\n\\nThe City of Calabasas confirmed the news of the crash with a statement on Twitter.\\n\\nThey wrote: \\\"This information is preliminary and subject to change.\\n\\n\\\"An S-76 helicopter crashed this morning under unknown circumstances near Calabasas
column29: California.\\n\\n\\\"Local authorities say that five people were on board.\\\"\\n\\nA video of a completely different crash was shared on social by someone who said it showed Bryant's helicopter.\\n\\nThe sick post caused outrage from the star's millions of fans worldwide.\\n\\nWitnesses saw the helicopter in distress

column26: when something happens you don't see the ground coming.\\\"\\n\\nThe experienced pilot continued to talk about the conditions in the last few days.\\n\\nHe said: \\\"Even last night there were no LAPD helicopters because of poor visibility.\\n\\n\\\"I checked the weather this morning around the time of the crash and it was low visibility everywhere in Los Angeles.\\n\\n\\\"If I fly above the fog and my engine quits

column28: I cannot see and everybody dies. So when I was there I just turned around the fog.\\n\\n\\\"When you have one problem in a helicopter you have to fix it because the second problem is going to kill you.\\n\\n\\\"So when you have bad weather you don't push it because if something happens there's very little space to maneuver.\\n\\n\\\"I'm sure this pilot would have known that area. But he must have got surprised. And that type of helicopter can travel up to 115mph.\\\"\\n\\nThe Sun also listened to the dispatch call made after the crash.\\n\\nEmergency dispatchers could be heard saying: \\\"We do have one copter 300 yards east of this location. text: former us president barack obama mourned the heartbreaking loss of the nba great and his teenage daughter

column9: \"title\": \"Kobe Bryant dead at 41: NBA legend killed along with his daughter
column11: as his helicopter crashes in fog\"
column12: \"content\": \"NBA legend Kobe Bryant and his oldest daughter
column13: Gianna
column14: were killed in a fiery helicopter crash in California today.\\n\\nTMZ was the first to confirm that the 41-year-old and his daughter were on their way to the Mamba Academy for a basketball practice when the private helicopter went down at around 10 a.m. PST.\\n\\nThe website later reported that Gianna did not survive the crash. She was 13.\\n\\nOrange Coast College baseball coach John Altobelli
column15: his wife Kerry
column16: and their daughter Alyssa were also among the nine people killed in the crash
column17: officials said.\\n\\nAs news of the tragic accident emerged
column18: the sports world and beyond memorialized the basketball legend on Twitter.\\n\\nA \\\"shocked\\\" Michael Jordan lamented the passing of his \\\"little brother\\\" and the \\\"amazing dad.\\\"\\n\\nFormer teammate and Lakers star Shaquille O'Neal was \\\"sick\\\" and speechless over the loss of his \\\"niece\\\" and \\\"brother.\\\"\\n\\nFormer US President Barack Obama mourned the \\\"heartbreaking\\\" loss of the NBA great and his teenage daughter.\\n\\nBryant's helicopter took off from Long Beach at 8:29 a.m PST on Sunday
column19: then touched down again just eight minutes later in Orange County.\\n\\nIt is believed the stop was to pick up Bryant and the other passengers.\\n\\nThe helicopter then took off again 30 minutes later at 9:06 a.m. PST but never reached its final destination.\\n\\nThe helicopter spent around 12 minutes circling above Burbank
column20: California
column21: halfway through its flight
column22: before setting off on the fateful finally leg.\\n\\nExperienced LA helicopter pilot Phillipe Lesourd thinks this may have been to wait before getting clearance to continue their journey because of the bad weather.\\n\\nThe helicopter came down in what's been described as very foggy conditions
column24: which is home to many celebrities.\\n\\nIt's reported the helicopter crashed behind Kourtney Kardashian's home.\\n\\nLesourd talked to The Sun about the weather conditions.\\n\\nHe said: \\\"The visibility was so bad... The conditions were very
column25: very poor.\\n\\n\\\"I flew with my wife last week and there was fog inside the Malibu Canyon and we turned around because there was no visibility. Today would have been even worse.\\n\\n\\\"When there is no visibility
column26: when something happens you don't see the ground coming.\\\"\\n\\nThe experienced pilot continued to talk about the conditions in the last few days.\\n\\nHe said: \\\"Even last night there were no LAPD helicopters because of poor visibility.\\n\\n\\\"I checked the weather this morning around the time of the crash and it was low visibility everywhere in Los Angeles.\\n\\n\\\"If I fly above the fog and my engine quits
column27: or I have another problem and I have to land
column28: I cannot see and everybody dies. So when I was there I just turned around the fog.\\n\\n\\\"When you have one problem in a helicopter you have to fix it because the second problem is going to kill you.\\n\\n\\\"So when you have bad weather you don't push it because if something happens there's very little space to maneuver.\\n\\n\\\"I'm sure this pilot would have known that area. But he must have got surprised. And that type of helicopter can travel up to 115mph.\\\"\\n\\nThe Sun also listened to the dispatch call made after the crash.\\n\\nEmergency dispatchers could be heard saying: \\\"We do have one copter 300 yards east of this location. A chopper down. All units for assignment.\\\"\\n\\nReports of a \\\"small plane down with brush involved\\\" were the first indication of the tragedy in Calabasas.\\n\\nThe City of Calabasas confirmed the news of the crash with a statement on Twitter.\\n\\nThey wrote: \\\"This information is preliminary and subject to change.\\n\\n\\\"An S-76 helicopter crashed this morning under unknown circumstances near Calabasas
column29: California.\\n\\n\\\"Local authorities say that five people were on board.\\\"\\n\\nA video of a completely different crash was shared on social by someone who said it showed Bryant's helicopter.\\n\\nThe sick post caused outrage from the star's millions of fans worldwide.\\n\\nWitnesses saw the helicopter in distress
column30: LA County Fire Capt. Tony Imbrenda told reporters.\\n\\nIt is not known whether the pilot alerted over radio that the aircraft was in trouble.\\n\\nThe Federal Aviation Administration said the Sikorsky S-76 crashed under \\\"unknown circumstances.\\\"\\n\\nL.A. Times reporter Richard Winton reported the mountains were \\\"fogged in.\\\"\\n\\n\\\"I heard the plane splutter and then a boom
column31: \\\" he tweeted.\\n\\nBryant\\u2019s visibly shocked stepfather-in-law Stephen Laine - who helped raise Bryant's wife Vanessa - told The Sun: \\u201cI just found out and can\\u2019t say much
column32: just that I wish the family well.\\n\\n\\u201cI just heard on the news that Gianna died as well. It\\u2019s terrible.\\n\\n\\u201cMy heart goes out to Vanessa and the kids.\\u201d\\n\\nLos Angeles Clippers coach Doc Rivers
column33: who helmed the Boston Celtics in 2008 when the team beat Bryant\\u2019s Lakers in the NBA finals
column34: said: \\u2018He had that DNA that very athletes can ever have.\\u201d\\n\\nA visibly emotional Rivers added: \\u201cThe news is just devastating to everybody who knew him.\\u201d\\n\\nLos Angeles Lakers star LeBron James
column35: who last night passed Bryant for third place on the NBA's all-time scoring list
column36: was noticeably upset as he exited the Lakers plane today.\\n\\nVideo showed James embracing someone and appearing to become emotional as the reality of Bryant's death set in.\\n\\nBryant's last tweet on his social media was a congratulatory message to James.\\n\\nThe tweet read: \\\"Continuing to move the game forward. Much respect my brother #33644.\\\"\\n\\nBryant spoke about his love for flying to GQ Magazine in 2010 and mentioned that helicopter was his preferred mode of transportation.\\n\\nThe father-of-four transcended sports and was recognized as one of the greatest players ever to take to the court.\\n\\nBasketball fans and players alike often referred to Bryant by his self-bestowed moniker 'The Black Mamba'- an extremely venomous snake that personified his lethal attitude towards competition on the court.\\n\\nTributes have started to flood social media
column37: with several of his fellow NBA players
column38: past and present
column39: chiming in.\\n\\nBryant's longtime teammate Shaquille O'Neal
column40: with whom he had a sometimes-contentious relationship
column41: commented. Despite some testy interactions
column42: the two teamed up to be a championship force for LA.\\n\\nHe tweeted out: \\\"There\\u2019s no words to express the pain I'm going through with this tragedy of losing my niece Gigi & my brother.\\n\\n\\\"I love u and u will be missed. My condolences goes out to the Bryant family and the families of the other passengers on board. IM SICK RIGHT NOW.\\\"\\n\\n\\\"Reports are that basketball great Kobe Bryant and three others have been killed in a helicopter crash in California
column43: \\\" wrote President Trump.\\n\\n\\\"I am in shock over the tragic newsing dad who loved his family deeply - and took great pride in his daughter's love for the game of basketball.\\\" of Kobe's and Gianna's passing
column44: \\\" Jordan said in a statement on Sunday.\\n\\n\\\"I loved Kobe - he was like a little brother to me. He was a fierce competitor
column45: one of the greats of the game and a creative force.\\n\\n\\\"Kobe was also an amazing dad who loved his family deeply - and took great pride in his daughter's love for the game of basketball.\\\"\\n\\n\\\"Kobe was a legend on the court and just getting started in what would have been just as meaningful a second act
column46: \\\" wrote Obama
column47: referencing the Mamba Sports Academy training facility Bryant opened in 2018
column48: according to Bleacher Report.\\n\\n\\\"To lose Gianna is even more heartbreaking to us as parents.\\n\\n\\\"Michelle and I send love and prayers to Vanessa and the entire Bryant family on an unthinkable day.\\\"\\n\\nNBA all-timer Bill Russell tweeted out: \\\"Jeannine & I are absolutely shocked to hear of the loss of one of my favorite people & one of the best basketball minds in the history of the game! Our hearts & prayers to Vanessa & his girls.\\n\\n\\\"You were my biggest fan
column49: but I was yours #RIPMAMBA\\\".\\n\\nDominique Wilkins wrote: \\\"I have no words
column50: God speed my friend. You are a legend.\\\"\\n\\nWhile NBA legend Scottie Pippen wrote: \\\"I\\u2019m stunned. Words can\\u2019t even come close to describing it. Just an incredibly sad and tragic day.\\\"\\n\\nAnd Tony Parker posted: \\\"I\\u2019m heartbroken by this news
column51: you were a true legend
column52: and friend. Rest In Peace. My thoughts and prayers to his wife and kids. #legend #mamba #goat\\\"\\n\\nFans have gathered around a makeshift memorial outside of the Staples Center in Los Angeles
column54: where the 62nd annual Grammy Awards will be held tonight.\\n\\nThey comforted one another while holding up posters and adorning the front of the arena with bouquets of flowers
column56: cards and snapshots of Bryant in action.\\n\\nThe Houston Rockets and the Denver Nuggets also had a minute of silence for the basketball player.\\n\\nAustin Rivers
column58: Kawhi Leonard
column59: and former teammate and Los Angeles Clippers coach Tyronn Lue were spotted holding back tears.\\n\\nBryant spent his entire 20-year career with the Los Angeles Lakers and led the team to five NBA championships while starring in 18 All-Star games.\\n\\nThe Philadelphia native was drafted into the NBA straight out of high school in 1996 by the Charlotte Hornets
column60: but was eventually traded to the Lakers.\\n\\nBryant
column61: who retired in 2016
column62: spent his first 10 seasons wearing No 8 and his final 10 in No 24
column63: with The Lakers retiring both jerseys.\\n\\nForming a formidable partnership with Shaquille O'Neal on court
column64: the 41-year-old led the LA side to three back-to-back NBA championships from 2000-2002.\\n\\nHe became the first basketball player to win an Oscar for best short animated film in 2018 for Dear Basketball
column65: a five-minute film based on a love letter to the sport he had written in 2015.\"

column12: \"content\": \"NBA legend Kobe Bryant and his oldest daughter
column13: Gianna
column14: were killed in a fiery helicopter crash in California today.\\n\\nTMZ was the first to confirm that the 41-year-old and his daughter were on their way to the Mamba Academy for a basketball practice when the private helicopter went down at around 10 a.m. PST.\\n\\nThe website later reported that Gianna did not survive the crash. She was 13.\\n\\nOrange Coast College baseball coach John Altobelli
column15: his wife Kerry
column16: and their daughter Alyssa were also among the nine people killed in the crash
column17: officials said.\\n\\nAs news of the tragic accident emerged
column18: the sports world and beyond memorialized the basketball legend on Twitter.\\n\\nA \\\"shocked\\\" Michael Jordan lamented the passing of his \\\"little brother\\\" and the \\\"amazing dad.\\\"\\n\\nFormer teammate and Lakers star Shaquille O'Neal was \\\"sick\\\" and speechless over the loss of his \\\"niece\\\" and \\\"brother.\\\"\\n\\nFormer US President Barack Obama mourned the \\\"heartbreaking\\\" loss of the NBA great and his teenage daughter.\\n\\nBryant's helicopter took off from Long Beach at 8:29 a.m PST on Sunday
column19: then touched down again just eight minutes later in Orange County.\\n\\nIt is believed the stop was to pick up Bryant and the other passengers.\\n\\nThe helicopter then took off again 30 minutes later at 9:06 a.m. PST but never reached its final destination.\\n\\nThe helicopter spent around 12 minutes circling above Burbank
column20: California
column21: halfway through its flight
column22: before setting off on the fateful finally leg.\\n\\nExperienced LA helicopter pilot Phillipe Lesourd thinks this may have been to wait before getting clearance to continue their journey because of the bad weather.\\n\\nThe helicopter came down in what's been described as very foggy conditions
column24: which is home to many celebrities.\\n\\nIt's reported the helicopter crashed behind Kourtney Kardashian's home.\\n\\nLesourd talked to The Sun about the weather conditions.\\n\\nHe said: \\\"The visibility was so bad... The conditions were very
column25: very poor.\\n\\n\\\"I flew with my wife last week and there was fog inside the Malibu Canyon and we turned around because there was no visibility. Today would have been even worse.\\n\\n\\\"When there is no visibility
column26: when something happens you don't see the ground coming.\\\"\\n\\nThe experienced pilot continued to talk about the conditions in the last few days.\\n\\nHe said: \\\"Even last night there were no LAPD helicopters because of poor visibility.\\n\\n\\\"I checked the weather this morning around the time of the crash and it was low visibility everywhere in Los Angeles.\\n\\n\\\"If I fly above the fog and my engine quits
column27: or I have another problem and I have to land
column28: I cannot see and everybody dies. So when I was there I just turned around the fog.\\n\\n\\\"When you have one problem in a helicopter you have to fix it because the second problem is going to kill you.\\n\\n\\\"So when you have bad weather you don't push it because if something happens there's very little space to maneuver.\\n\\n\\\"I'm sure this pilot would have known that area. But he must have got surprised. And that type of helicopter can travel up to 115mph.\\\"\\n\\nThe Sun also listened to the dispatch call made after the crash.\\n\\nEmergency dispatchers could be heard saying: \\\"We do have one copter 300 yards east of this location. A chopper down. All units for assignment.\\\"\\n\\nReports of a \\\"small plane down with brush involved\\\" were the first indication of the tragedy in Calabasas.\\n\\nThe City of Calabasas confirmed the news of the crash with a statement on Twitter.\\n\\nThey wrote: \\\"This information is preliminary and subject to change.\\n\\n\\\"An S-76 helicopter crashed this morning under unknown circumstances near Calabasas
column29: California.\\n\\n\\\"Local authorities say that five people were on board.\\\"\\n\\nA video of a completely different crash was shared on social by someone who said it showed Bryant's helicopter.\\n\\nThe sick post caused outrage from the star's millions of fans worldwide.\\n\\nWitnesses saw the helicopter in distress

column10: suggesting that Trump supporters are a bunch of knuckle-dragging xenophobes whose only reason for wanting a wall on the Mexican border is because they suffer an aversion to people with different skin color than them.What exactly do White Americans - who opened the floodgates to immigration in 1965 - need to do these days to prove they are not natural born racists? Cancel their monthly subscription to Town and Country? Stop walking their dogs
column11: which are
column12: of course
column13: four-legged vehicles of \\\"racial segregation
column14: \\\" or stop attending their evening yoga class
column15: the unsuspecting breeding grounds for white supremacists? Somehow I suspect that even if White people took to burning effigies of Ku Klux Klan members on their manicured front lawns that would not even put a stop to the ugly rumors. Let's just face it
column16: the only thing that will finally stop the slanderous slurs is if all White Americans publicly denounce their support of the biggest race-hater of them all
column17: Donald J. Trump. And should they refuse the itinerant Liberal Inquisition will be only too happy to do it for them.Just ask Noah Berlatsky
column18: occasional columnist for MSNBC
column19: whose latest piece was crowned with the zinger of a headline
column20: 'Trump voters motivated by racism may be violating the Constitution. Can they be stopped?' Nice leading question there
column21: but the premise that precedes it
column22: that Trump voters are \\\"motivated by racism
column23: \\\" is just one more election-season deceit.Berlatsky's article opens with the conclusion that Donald Trump \\\"ran an openly racist campaign for president
column24: \\\" and that his popular rallying slogan \\\"Make America Great Again\\\" is actually code that can be translated into \\\"America was greater when white people's power was more sweeping and more secure.\\\" Yet nowhere in any of Trump's numerous campaign utterances or even Tweets has he ever singled out America's White population as the intended sole beneficiary of his plans to remake the U.S. economy. In fact
column25: just the opposite. As Trump has made it his goal to return some of the shine to America's industrial Rustbelt
column26: threatening companies with penalties and public scorn if they relocate their production operations overseas
column27: the unemployment rate among Blacks now stands at 5.9%
column28: down from 7.5% at the start of his presidency. At the same time
column29: the employment rate among Hispanics is at historic highs.At this point
column30: the Democrats will invariably mention Trump's promise to build a wall on the U.S.-Mexican border
column31: a promise that arguably won the real estate developer the White House in 2016. Yet Trump
column33: is an unrepentant racist\\\"When Mexico sends its people
column34: they're not sending their best...They're sending people that have lots of problems
column35: and they're bringing those problems with us. They're bringing drugs. They're bringing crime. They're rapists. And some
column37: are good people.\\\"Trump was not arguing
column38: of course
column39: that all Mexicans are rapists or criminals. He was arguing that of the many who do make it across the border a disproportionate number do fit the description.Suffice it to consider a comment by a British tourist to San Francisco
column40: the one-time crown gem of the increasingly tarnished
column41: Democratic-controlled Golden State: \\\"I can't understand how anyone can live in a place where their everyday trip to get groceries or go to work includes a multitude of beggars asking for spare change or a meal.\\\"Considering that the Democrats can't even take care of their own burgeoning problems in their primary constituencies
column43: these are the very same people who screamed 'not in my backyard!' when Trump threatened to send all apprehended illegals to the so-called 'sanctuary cities'. Nancy Pelosi skirted the periphery of racism when she called the idea \\\"disrespectful.\\\"Was New York Governor Andrew Cuomo motivated by pure compassion when he signed legislation granting driver's licenses to illegal immigrants
column44: who may now cast a 'legal' vote under New York's notoriously loose voting laws? Now Democrats are demanding the elimination Voter ID rules
column45: declaring them racist against minorities. This is one of the ways Berlatsky proposes to end so-called \\\"racist voting\\\" now purportedly contaminating U.S. politics.In the final analysis
column46: the Democrat's groundless assertion that Trump supporters are kneejerk racists disintegrates when it is remembered that up to 10 million former Obama supporters - many of them White - switched allegiances to the Trump camp in the 2016 presidential election. Are we really expected to believe that all of those Americans suddenly became hardcore racists with the arrival of the evil 'orange man' and his pledge to build a wall? That sounds highly unlikely. The far more logical explanation for this massive change in political sentiment is that Trump's plan to remedy America's dangerously porous borders
column47: thereby enhancing the security of all Americans
column48: regardless of skin color
column49: was a welcomed idea across the board.Nevertheless
column50: the real danger is that the Democrats
column51: entranced by the cult of political correctness and an out-of-control cancel culture
column52: will attempt by some extreme measures to identify and ban so-called 'racist Trump supporters' who are just regular Americans looking for a leader who will provide them with a well-guarded country that protects the rights of all its citizens regardless of skin color. Banning undesirable Trump voters from the ballet box may eventually become as easy as censoring right-leaning Twitter users.- to quote Hillary Clinton - and have only worsened their present position by calling these same voters
column53: many of them former Obama supporters
column54: \\\"racist.\\\" Such a gross simplification and misunderstanding of the current American political realities goes far at explaining why the Democrats stand very little chance of beating Trump at the ballot box.\"

text: greenhouse gas emissions worse than ever in 2019

column7: \"title\": \"Greenhouse Gas Emissions Worse Than Ever in 2019\"
column8: \"content\": \"Global emissions for 2019 are predicted to hit 36.8 billion tonnes of carbon dioxide (CO\\u2082)
column9: setting yet another all-time record. This disturbing result means emissions have grown by 62% since international climate negotiations began in 1990 to address the problem.\\n\\nThe figures are contained in the Global Carbon Project
column10: which today released its 14th Global Carbon Budget.\\n\\nDigging into the numbers
column11: however
column12: reveals a silver lining. While overall carbon emissions continue to rise
column13: the rate of growth is about two-thirds lower than in the previous two years.\\n\\nDriving this slower growth is an extraordinary decline in coal emissions
column14: particularly in the United States and Europe
column15: and growth in renewable energy globally.\\n\\nA less positive component of this emissions slowdown
column17: is that a lower global economic growth has contributed to it. Most concerning yet is the very robust and stable upward trends in emissions from oil and natural gas.\\n\\nThe burning of coal continues to dominate CO\\u2082 emissions and was responsible for 40% of all fossil fuel emissions in 2018
column18: followed by oil (34%) and natural gas (20%). However
column19: coal emissions reached their highest levels in 2012 and have remained slightly lower since then. Emissions have been declining at an annual average of 0.5% over the past five years to 2018.\\n\\nCoal emissions hit a peak in 2012 and have been declining ever since. Global Carbon Project 2019\\n\\nIn 2019
column20: we project a further decline in global coal CO\\u2082 emissions of around 0.9%. This decline is due to large falls of 10% in both the US and the European Union
column21: and weak growth in China (0.8%) and India (2%).\\n\\nThe US has announced the closure of more than 500 coal-fired power plants over the past decade
column22: while the UK\\u2019s electricity sector has gone from 40% coal-based power in 2012 to 5% in 2018.\\n\\nWhether coal emissions reached a true peak in 2012 or will creep back up will depend largely on the trajectory of coal use in China and India. Despite this uncertainty
column23: the strong upward trend from the past has been broken and is unlikely to return.\\n\\nCO\\u2082 emissions from oil and natural gas in particular have grown robustly for decades and show no signs of slowing down. In fact
column24: while emissions growth from oil has been fairly steady over the past decade at 1.4% a year
column25: emissions from natural gas have grown almost twice as fast at 2.4% a year
column26: and are estimated to further accelerate to 2.6% in 2019. Natural gas is the single largest contributor to this year\\u2019s increase in global CO\\u2082 emissions.\\n\\nThis uptick in natural gas consumption is driven by a range of factors. New
column27: \\u201cunconventional\\u201d methods of extracting natural gas in the US have increased production. This boom is in part replacing coal for electricity generation.\\n\\nRead more: How to answer the argument that Australia's emissions are too small to make a difference\\n\\nIn Japan
column28: natural gas is filling the void left by nuclear power after the Fukushima disaster. In most of the rest of the world
column29: new natural gas capacity is primarily filling new energy demand.\\n\\nOil emissions
column30: on the other hand
column31: are largely being driven by the rapidly growing transport sector. This is increasing across land
column33: but is dominated by road transport.\\n\\nAustralia\\u2019s emissions have also seen significant reductions from coal sources over the past decade
column34: while emissions from oil and natural gas have grown rapidly and are driving the country\\u2019s overall growth in fossil CO\\u2082 emissions.\\n\\nCO\\u2082 emissions from fossil fuels in Australia (in million tonnes). Data Source: UNFCCC
column35: CDIAC
column37: USGS \\n\\n\\n\\nPreliminary estimates for 2019 show that global emissions from deforestation
column38: fires and other land-use changes reached 6 billion tonnes of CO\\u2082 \\u2013 about 0.8 billion tonnes above 2018 levels. The additional emissions largely come from elevated fire and deforestation activity in the Amazon and Southeast Asia.\\n\\nThe accelerated loss of forests in 2019 not only leads to higher emissions
column39: but reduces the capacity of vegetation to act as a \\u201csink\\u201d removing CO\\u2082 from the atmosphere. This is deeply concerning
column40: as the world\\u2019s oceans and plants absorb about half of all CO\\u2082 emissions from human activities. They are one of our most effective buffers against even higher CO\\u2082 concentrations in the atmosphere
column41: and must be safeguarded.\\n\\nFires and deforestation in the Amazon and Southeast Asia drove a new record high in land-related emissions. Global Carbon Project 2019\\n\\nNot all sinks can be managed by people \\u2013 the open ocean sink being an example \\u2013 but land-based sinks can be actively protected by preventing deforestation and degradation
column42: and further enhanced by ecosystem restoration and reforestation.\\n\\nFor every year in which global emissions grow
column43: the goals of the Paris Agreement are one step further removed from being achievable. We know many ways to decarbonise economies that are good for people and the environment. Some countries are showing it is possible. It is time for the rest of the world to join them.\\n\\nCorinne Le Qu\\u00e9r\\u00e9 receives funding from the European Commission (Horizon 2020)
column44: the UK Research Councils
column45: the Royal Society. She has previously held funding from the UK Government Department for Business
column46: Energy and Industrial Strategy. She is member of the UK Committee on Climate Change
column47: and Chairs France's Haut conseil pour le climat.\\n\\nPierre Friedlingstein receives funding from the European Union\\u2019s Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme.\\n\\nRobbie Andrew receives funding from the European Union\\u2019s Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme.\\n\\nRob Jackson receives current funding from the U.S. Department of Agriculture
column48: the Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation
column49: and the California Department of Energy.\\n\\nTheir article first appeared in The Conversation in December 2019.\"

text: digging into the numbers however reveals a silver lining
source: {\id\": \"nationalinterest--2020-01-26--Greenhouse Gas Emissions Worse Than Ever in 2019\"
column7: \"title\": \"Greenhouse Gas Emissions Worse Than Ever in 2019\"
column8: \"content\": \"Global emissions for 2019 are predicted to hit 36.8 billion tonnes of carbon dioxide (CO\\u2082)
column9: setting yet another all-time record. This disturbing result means emissions have grown by 62% since international climate negotiations began in 1990 to address the problem.\\n\\nThe figures are contained in the Global Carbon Project
column10: which today released its 14th Global Carbon Budget.\\n\\nDigging into the numbers
column11: however
column12: reveals a silver lining. While overall carbon emissions continue to rise
column13: the rate of growth is about two-thirds lower than in the previous two years.\\n\\nDriving this slower growth is an extraordinary decline in coal emissions
column14: particularly in the United States and Europe
column15: and growth in renewable energy globally.\\n\\nA less positive component of this emissions slowdown
column17: is that a lower global economic growth has contributed to it. Most concerning yet is the very robust and stable upward trends in emissions from oil and natural gas.\\n\\nThe burning of coal continues to dominate CO\\u2082 emissions and was responsible for 40% of all fossil fuel emissions in 2018
column18: followed by oil (34%) and natural gas (20%). However
column19: coal emissions reached their highest levels in 2012 and have remained slightly lower since then. Emissions have been declining at an annual average of 0.5% over the past five years to 2018.\\n\\nCoal emissions hit a peak in 2012 and have been declining ever since. Global Carbon Project 2019\\n\\nIn 2019
column20: we project a further decline in global coal CO\\u2082 emissions of around 0.9%. This decline is due to large falls of 10% in both the US and the European Union
column21: and weak growth in China (0.8%) and India (2%).\\n\\nThe US has announced the closure of more than 500 coal-fired power plants over the past decade
column22: while the UK\\u2019s electricity sector has gone from 40% coal-based power in 2012 to 5% in 2018.\\n\\nWhether coal emissions reached a true peak in 2012 or will creep back up will depend largely on the trajectory of coal use in China and India. Despite this uncertainty
column23: the strong upward trend from the past has been broken and is unlikely to return.\\n\\nCO\\u2082 emissions from oil and natural gas in particular have grown robustly for decades and show no signs of slowing down. In fact
column24: while emissions growth from oil has been fairly steady over the past decade at 1.4% a year
column25: emissions from natural gas have grown almost twice as fast at 2.4% a year
column26: and are estimated to further accelerate to 2.6% in 2019. Natural gas is the single largest contributor to this year\\u2019s increase in global CO\\u2082 emissions.\\n\\nThis uptick in natural gas consumption is driven by a range of factors. New
column27: \\u201cunconventional\\u201d methods of extracting natural gas in the US have increased production. This boom is in part replacing coal for electricity generation.\\n\\nRead more: How to answer the argument that Australia's emissions are too small to make a difference\\n\\nIn Japan
column28: natural gas is filling the void left by nuclear power after the Fukushima disaster. In most of the rest of the world
column29: new natural gas capacity is primarily filling new energy demand.\\n\\nOil emissions
column30: on the other hand
column31: are largely being driven by the rapidly growing transport sector. This is increasing across land
column33: but is dominated by road transport.\\n\\nAustralia\\u2019s emissions have also seen significant reductions from coal sources over the past decade
column34: while emissions from oil and natural gas have grown rapidly and are driving the country\\u2019s overall growth in fossil CO\\u2082 emissions.\\n\\nCO\\u2082 emissions from fossil fuels in Australia (in million tonnes). Data Source: UNFCCC
column35: CDIAC
column37: USGS \\n\\n\\n\\nPreliminary estimates for 2019 show that global emissions from deforestation
column38: fires and other land-use changes reached 6 billion tonnes of CO\\u2082 \\u2013 about 0.8 billion tonnes above 2018 levels. The additional emissions largely come from elevated fire and deforestation activity in the Amazon and Southeast Asia.\\n\\nThe accelerated loss of forests in 2019 not only leads to higher emissions
column39: but reduces the capacity of vegetation to act as a \\u201csink\\u201d removing CO\\u2082 from the atmosphere. This is deeply concerning
column40: as the world\\u2019s oceans and plants absorb about half of all CO\\u2082 emissions from human activities. They are one of our most effective buffers against even higher CO\\u2082 concentrations in the atmosphere
column41: and must be safeguarded.\\n\\nFires and deforestation in the Amazon and Southeast Asia drove a new record high in land-related emissions. Global Carbon Project 2019\\n\\nNot all sinks can be managed by people \\u2013 the open ocean sink being an example \\u2013 but land-based sinks can be actively protected by preventing deforestation and degradation
column42: and further enhanced by ecosystem restoration and reforestation.\\n\\nFor every year in which global emissions grow
column43: the goals of the Paris Agreement are one step further removed from being achievable. We know many ways to decarbonise economies that are good for people and the environment. Some countries are showing it is possible. It is time for the rest of the world to join them.\\n\\nCorinne Le Qu\\u00e9r\\u00e9 receives funding from the European Commission (Horizon 2020)
column44: the UK Research Councils
column45: the Royal Society. She has previously held funding from the UK Government Department for Business
column46: Energy and Industrial Strategy. She is member of the UK Committee on Climate Change
column47: and Chairs France's Haut conseil pour le climat.\\n\\nPierre Friedlingstein receives funding from the European Union\\u2019s Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme.\\n\\nRobbie Andrew receives funding from the European Union\\u2019s Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme.\\n\\nRob Jackson receives current funding from the U.S. Department of Agriculture
column48: the Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation
column49: and the California Department of Energy.\\n\\nTheir article first appeared in The Conversation in December 2019.\"

text: the burning of coal continues to dominate co emissions and was responsible for 40 of all fossil fuel emissions in 2018 followed by oil 34 and natural gas 20
source: {\id\": \"nationalinterest--2020-01-26--Greenhouse Gas Emissions Worse Than Ever in 2019\"
column7: \"title\": \"Greenhouse Gas Emissions Worse Than Ever in 2019\"
column8: \"content\": \"Global emissions for 2019 are predicted to hit 36.8 billion tonnes of carbon dioxide (CO\\u2082)
column9: setting yet another all-time record. This disturbing result means emissions have grown by 62% since international climate negotiations began in 1990 to address the problem.\\n\\nThe figures are contained in the Global Carbon Project
column10: which today released its 14th Global Carbon Budget.\\n\\nDigging into the numbers
column11: however
column12: reveals a silver lining. While overall carbon emissions continue to rise
column13: the rate of growth is about two-thirds lower than in the previous two years.\\n\\nDriving this slower growth is an extraordinary decline in coal emissions
column14: particularly in the United States and Europe
column15: and growth in renewable energy globally.\\n\\nA less positive component of this emissions slowdown
column17: is that a lower global economic growth has contributed to it. Most concerning yet is the very robust and stable upward trends in emissions from oil and natural gas.\\n\\nThe burning of coal continues to dominate CO\\u2082 emissions and was responsible for 40% of all fossil fuel emissions in 2018
column18: followed by oil (34%) and natural gas (20%). However
column19: coal emissions reached their highest levels in 2012 and have remained slightly lower since then. Emissions have been declining at an annual average of 0.5% over the past five years to 2018.\\n\\nCoal emissions hit a peak in 2012 and have been declining ever since. Global Carbon Project 2019\\n\\nIn 2019
column20: we project a further decline in global coal CO\\u2082 emissions of around 0.9%. This decline is due to large falls of 10% in both the US and the European Union
column21: and weak growth in China (0.8%) and India (2%).\\n\\nThe US has announced the closure of more than 500 coal-fired power plants over the past decade
column22: while the UK\\u2019s electricity sector has gone from 40% coal-based power in 2012 to 5% in 2018.\\n\\nWhether coal emissions reached a true peak in 2012 or will creep back up will depend largely on the trajectory of coal use in China and India. Despite this uncertainty
column23: the strong upward trend from the past has been broken and is unlikely to return.\\n\\nCO\\u2082 emissions from oil and natural gas in particular have grown robustly for decades and show no signs of slowing down. In fact
column24: while emissions growth from oil has been fairly steady over the past decade at 1.4% a year
column25: emissions from natural gas have grown almost twice as fast at 2.4% a year
column26: and are estimated to further accelerate to 2.6% in 2019. Natural gas is the single largest contributor to this year\\u2019s increase in global CO\\u2082 emissions.\\n\\nThis uptick in natural gas consumption is driven by a range of factors. New
column27: \\u201cunconventional\\u201d methods of extracting natural gas in the US have increased production. This boom is in part replacing coal for electricity generation.\\n\\nRead more: How to answer the argument that Australia's emissions are too small to make a difference\\n\\nIn Japan
column28: natural gas is filling the void left by nuclear power after the Fukushima disaster. In most of the rest of the world
column29: new natural gas capacity is primarily filling new energy demand.\\n\\nOil emissions
column30: on the other hand
column31: are largely being driven by the rapidly growing transport sector. This is increasing across land
column33: but is dominated by road transport.\\n\\nAustralia\\u2019s emissions have also seen significant reductions from coal sources over the past decade
column34: while emissions from oil and natural gas have grown rapidly and are driving the country\\u2019s overall growth in fossil CO\\u2082 emissions.\\n\\nCO\\u2082 emissions from fossil fuels in Australia (in million tonnes). Data Source: UNFCCC
column35: CDIAC
column37: USGS \\n\\n\\n\\nPreliminary estimates for 2019 show that global emissions from deforestation
column38: fires and other land-use changes reached 6 billion tonnes of CO\\u2082 \\u2013 about 0.8 billion tonnes above 2018 levels. The additional emissions largely come from elevated fire and deforestation activity in the Amazon and Southeast Asia.\\n\\nThe accelerated loss of forests in 2019 not only leads to higher emissions
column39: but reduces the capacity of vegetation to act as a \\u201csink\\u201d removing CO\\u2082 from the atmosphere. This is deeply concerning
column40: as the world\\u2019s oceans and plants absorb about half of all CO\\u2082 emissions from human activities. They are one of our most effective buffers against even higher CO\\u2082 concentrations in the atmosphere
column41: and must be safeguarded.\\n\\nFires and deforestation in the Amazon and Southeast Asia drove a new record high in land-related emissions. Global Carbon Project 2019\\n\\nNot all sinks can be managed by people \\u2013 the open ocean sink being an example \\u2013 but land-based sinks can be actively protected by preventing deforestation and degradation
column42: and further enhanced by ecosystem restoration and reforestation.\\n\\nFor every year in which global emissions grow
column43: the goals of the Paris Agreement are one step further removed from being achievable. We know many ways to decarbonise economies that are good for people and the environment. Some countries are showing it is possible. It is time for the rest of the world to join them.\\n\\nCorinne Le Qu\\u00e9r\\u00e9 receives funding from the European Commission (Horizon 2020)

column45: the Royal Society. She has previously held funding from the UK Government Department for Business
column46: Energy and Industrial Strategy. She is member of the UK Committee on Climate Change
column47: and Chairs France's Haut conseil pour le climat.\\n\\nPierre Friedlingstein receives funding from the European Union\\u2019s Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme.\\n\\nRobbie Andrew receives funding from the European Union\\u2019s Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme.\\n\\nRob Jackson receives current funding from the U.S. Department of Agriculture
column48: the Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation
column49: and the California Department of Energy.\\n\\nTheir article first appeared in The Conversation in December 2019.\"

text: in 2019 we project a further decline in global coal co emissions of around 09
source: {\id\": \"nationalinterest--2020-01-26--Greenhouse Gas Emissions Worse Than Ever in 2019\"
column7: \"title\": \"Greenhouse Gas Emissions Worse Than Ever in 2019\"
column8: \"content\": \"Global emissions for 2019 are predicted to hit 36.8 billion tonnes of carbon dioxide (CO\\u2082)
column9: setting yet another all-time record. This disturbing result means emissions have grown by 62% since international climate negotiations began in 1990 to address the problem.\\n\\nThe figures are contained in the Global Carbon Project
column10: which today released its 14th Global Carbon Budget.\\n\\nDigging into the numbers
column11: however
column12: reveals a silver lining. While overall carbon emissions continue to rise
column13: the rate of growth is about two-thirds lower than in the previous two years.\\n\\nDriving this slower growth is an extraordinary decline in coal emissions
column14: particularly in the United States and Europe
column15: and growth in renewable energy globally.\\n\\nA less positive component of this emissions slowdown
column17: is that a lower global economic growth has contributed to it. Most concerning yet is the very robust and stable upward trends in emissions from oil and natural gas.\\n\\nThe burning of coal continues to dominate CO\\u2082 emissions and was responsible for 40% of all fossil fuel emissions in 2018
column18: followed by oil (34%) and natural gas (20%). However
column19: coal emissions reached their highest levels in 2012 and have remained slightly lower since then. Emissions have been declining at an annual average of 0.5% over the past five years to 2018.\\n\\nCoal emissions hit a peak in 2012 and have been declining ever since. Global Carbon Project 2019\\n\\nIn 2019
column20: we project a further decline in global coal CO\\u2082 emissions of around 0.9%. This decline is due to large falls of 10% in both the US and the European Union
column21: and weak growth in China (0.8%) and India (2%).\\n\\nThe US has announced the closure of more than 500 coal-fired power plants over the past decade
column22: while the UK\\u2019s electricity sector has gone from 40% coal-based power in 2012 to 5% in 2018.\\n\\nWhether coal emissions reached a true peak in 2012 or will creep back up will depend largely on the trajectory of coal use in China and India. Despite this uncertainty
column23: the strong upward trend from the past has been broken and is unlikely to return.\\n\\nCO\\u2082 emissions from oil and natural gas in particular have grown robustly for decades and show no signs of slowing down. In fact
column24: while emissions growth from oil has been fairly steady over the past decade at 1.4% a year
column25: emissions from natural gas have grown almost twice as fast at 2.4% a year
column26: and are estimated to further accelerate to 2.6% in 2019. Natural gas is the single largest contributor to this year\\u2019s increase in global CO\\u2082 emissions.\\n\\nThis uptick in natural gas consumption is driven by a range of factors. New
column27: \\u201cunconventional\\u201d methods of extracting natural gas in the US have increased production. This boom is in part replacing coal for electricity generation.\\n\\nRead more: How to answer the argument that Australia's emissions are too small to make a difference\\n\\nIn Japan
column28: natural gas is filling the void left by nuclear power after the Fukushima disaster. In most of the rest of the world
column29: new natural gas capacity is primarily filling new energy demand.\\n\\nOil emissions
column30: on the other hand
column31: are largely being driven by the rapidly growing transport sector. This is increasing across land
column33: but is dominated by road transport.\\n\\nAustralia\\u2019s emissions have also seen significant reductions from coal sources over the past decade
column34: while emissions from oil and natural gas have grown rapidly and are driving the country\\u2019s overall growth in fossil CO\\u2082 emissions.\\n\\nCO\\u2082 emissions from fossil fuels in Australia (in million tonnes). Data Source: UNFCCC
column35: CDIAC
column37: USGS \\n\\n\\n\\nPreliminary estimates for 2019 show that global emissions from deforestation
column38: fires and other land-use changes reached 6 billion tonnes of CO\\u2082 \\u2013 about 0.8 billion tonnes above 2018 levels. The additional emissions largely come from elevated fire and deforestation activity in the Amazon and Southeast Asia.\\n\\nThe accelerated loss of forests in 2019 not only leads to higher emissions
column39: but reduces the capacity of vegetation to act as a \\u201csink\\u201d removing CO\\u2082 from the atmosphere. This is deeply concerning
column40: as the world\\u2019s oceans and plants absorb about half of all CO\\u2082 emissions from human activities. They are one of our most effective buffers against even higher CO\\u2082 concentrations in the atmosphere
column41: and must be safeguarded.\\n\\nFires and deforestation in the Amazon and Southeast Asia drove a new record high in land-related emissions. Global Carbon Project 2019\\n\\nNot all sinks can be managed by people \\u2013 the open ocean sink being an example \\u2013 but land-based sinks can be actively protected by preventing deforestation and degradation
column42: and further enhanced by ecosystem restoration and reforestation.\\n\\nFor every year in which global emissions grow
column43: the goals of the Paris Agreement are one step further removed from being achievable. We know many ways to decarbonise economies that are good for people and the environment. Some countries are showing it is possible. It is time for the rest of the world to join them.\\n\\nCorinne Le Qu\\u00e9r\\u00e9 receives funding from the European Commission (Horizon 2020)
column44: the UK Research Councils
column45: the Royal Society. She has previously held funding from the UK Government Department for Business
column46: Energy and Industrial Strategy. She is member of the UK Committee on Climate Change
column47: and Chairs France's Haut conseil pour le climat.\\n\\nPierre Friedlingstein receives funding from the European Union\\u2019s Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme.\\n\\nRobbie Andrew receives funding from the European Union\\u2019s Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme.\\n\\nRob Jackson receives current funding from the U.S. Department of Agriculture
column48: the Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation
column49: and the California Department of Energy.\\n\\nTheir article first appeared in The Conversation in December 2019.\"

text: kobe bryant tributes pour in for basketball legend killed in helicopter crash aged 41 tributes are pouring in from across the world of sport after basketball legend kobe bryant was killed in a helicopter crash in california
source: {\id\": \"eveningstandard--2020-01-26--Kobe Bryant: Tributes pour in for basketball legend killed in helicopter crash aged 41\"
column7: \"title\": \"Kobe Bryant: Tributes pour in for basketball legend killed in helicopter crash aged 41\"
column8: \"content\": \"Tributes are pouring in from across the world of sport after basketball legend Kobe Bryant was killed in a helicopter crash in California.\\n\\nThe 41-year-old
column9: widely considered one of the greatest basketball players of all-time
column10: was killed when the aircraft crashed on Sunday morning
column11: with his 13-year-old daughter Gianna among eight other casualties.\\n\\nBryant spent his entire NBA career with the Los Angeles Lakers
column12: helping the franchise to five championship wins in his 20-year career.\\n\\nUS President Donald Trump tweeted: \\u201cReports are that basketball great Kobe Bryant and three others have been killed in a helicopter crash in California. That is terrible news!\\u201d\\n\\nTrump's predecessor
column13: Barack Obama
column14: a huge basketball fans
column15: tweeted: \\\"Kobe was a legend on the court and just getting started in what would have been just as meaningful a second act. To lose Gianna is even more heartbreaking to us as parents.\\\"\\n\\nFellow US sports star Tom Brady
column17: tweeted
column18: \\u201cWe miss you already Kobe\\u201d
column19: while Cleveland Browns quarterback Baker Mayfield called Bryant his \\u2018idol\\u2019.\\n\\nJoel Embiid
column20: star of the 76ers franchise based in Bryant\\u2019s hometown of Philadelphia
column21: said: \\u201cI started playing ball because of KOBE after watching the 2010 finals. I had never watched ball before that and that finals was the turning point of my life. I WANTED TO BE LIKE KOBE. I\\u2019m so FREAKING SAD right now!!!! RIP LEGEND.\\u201d\\n\\nFormer Miami Heat star Dwayne Wade tweeted simply: \\u201cNooooooooooo God please No!\\u201d
column22: while US women\\u2019s soccer forward Megan Rapinoe added: \\u201cHeart going out to the Bryant family right now. RIP.\\u201d\\n\\nLong time Lakers teammate Shaquille O'Neal tweeted: \\\"There\\u2019s no words to express the pain Im going through with this tragedy of loosing my neice Gigi & my brother @kobebryant. I love u and u will be missed. My condolences goes out to the Bryant family and the families of the other passengers on board. IM SICK RIGHT NOW.\\\"\\n\\nGary Lineker called Bryant \\u201cOne of the greatest sportsmen of our lifetime\\u201d
column23: while current England man Raheem Sterling tweeted: \\u201cRest easy
column24: legend.\\u201d\\n\\nBill Russell
column25: who won a staggering 11 NBA Championships with the Boston Celtics between 1957-1969
column26: said: \\u201c[Wife] Jeannine & I are absolutely shocked to hear of the loss of one of my favorite people & one of the best basketball minds in the history of the game! Our hearts & prayers to Vanessa & his girls. \\u200b\\n\\nAmerican comedian and TV host Ellen DeGeneres said she is \\u201cstunned and saddened\\u201d by the news that basketball star Kobe Bryant has died in a helicopter crash.\\n\\nShe said on Twitter: \\u201cLike everyone
column27: I\\u2019m stunned and saddened by the news about Kobe Bryant. My heart is broken for his wife and family.\\u201d\\n\\nA moment of silence was observed prior to the Denver Nuggets game against the Houston Rockets
column28: which took place shortly after news of Bryant\\u2019s death broke
column29: with fans heard chanting Bryant\\u2019s name
column30: and a similar tribute took place at the NFL's Pro-Bowl game in Orlando.\\n\\nGolfing great Tiger Woods
column31: a lifelong Lakers fan who shared a close friendship with Bryant
column32: was informed of the news by his caddie midway through his final round at the PGA Tour Farmers Insurance Open.\\n\\nCher tweeted: \\u201cIt\\u2019s SO HARD To Deal With The Death Of a GREAT STAR
column33: Because We Feel As If We Knew Them Personally.Kobe Bryant Was a GREAT ATHLETE
column34: & All Of America Will Feel His Loss.\\u201d\\n\\nUsing emojis
column35: she said her heart \\u201cgoes out to all Kobe\\u2019s family
column37: fans\\u201d and that the world had lost a \\u201cbright light\\u201d.\\n\\nUS politician Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez paid tribute to Bryant and the other passengers of the helicopter.\\n\\nShe said on Twitter: \\\"Deeply shocked at the news of Kobe Bryant and four others lost today. Sending all my thoughts to their families and loved ones in this devastating moment.\\\"\\n\\nSinger Justin Bieber posted a photo of himself as a child with Bryant on Instagram.\\n\\nHe posted the accompanying caption: \\\"It can't be. You always encouraged me mamba. Gave me me some of the best quotes that we smile about to this day! Love you man!\\\"\\n\\n\\\"Continuing to move the game forward (at) King James
column38: \\\" Bryant wrote in his last tweet. \\\"Much respect my brother.\\\"\"

column7: \"title\": \"Kobe Bryant: Tributes pour in for basketball legend killed in helicopter crash aged 41\"
column8: \"content\": \"Tributes are pouring in from across the world of sport after basketball legend Kobe Bryant was killed in a helicopter crash in California.\\n\\nThe 41-year-old
column9: widely considered one of the greatest basketball players of all-time
column10: was killed when the aircraft crashed on Sunday morning
column11: with his 13-year-old daughter Gianna among eight other casualties.\\n\\nBryant spent his entire NBA career with the Los Angeles Lakers
column12: helping the franchise to five championship wins in his 20-year career.\\n\\nUS President Donald Trump tweeted: \\u201cReports are that basketball great Kobe Bryant and three others have been killed in a helicopter crash in California. That is terrible news!\\u201d\\n\\nTrump's predecessor
column13: Barack Obama
column14: a huge basketball fans
column15: tweeted: \\\"Kobe was a legend on the court and just getting started in what would have been just as meaningful a second act. To lose Gianna is even more heartbreaking to us as parents.\\\"\\n\\nFellow US sports star Tom Brady
column17: tweeted
column18: \\u201cWe miss you already Kobe\\u201d
column19: while Cleveland Browns quarterback Baker Mayfield called Bryant his \\u2018idol\\u2019.\\n\\nJoel Embiid
column20: star of the 76ers franchise based in Bryant\\u2019s hometown of Philadelphia
column21: said: \\u201cI started playing ball because of KOBE after watching the 2010 finals. I had never watched ball before that and that finals was the turning point of my life. I WANTED TO BE LIKE KOBE. I\\u2019m so FREAKING SAD right now!!!! RIP LEGEND.\\u201d\\n\\nFormer Miami Heat star Dwayne Wade tweeted simply: \\u201cNooooooooooo God please No!\\u201d
column22: while US women\\u2019s soccer forward Megan Rapinoe added: \\u201cHeart going out to the Bryant family right now. RIP.\\u201d\\n\\nLong time Lakers teammate Shaquille O'Neal tweeted: \\\"There\\u2019s no words to express the pain Im going through with this tragedy of loosing my neice Gigi & my brother @kobebryant. I love u and u will be missed. My condolences goes out to the Bryant family and the families of the other passengers on board. IM SICK RIGHT NOW.\\\"\\n\\nGary Lineker called Bryant \\u201cOne of the greatest sportsmen of our lifetime\\u201d
column23: while current England man Raheem Sterling tweeted: \\u201cRest easy
column24: legend.\\u201d\\n\\nBill Russell
column25: who won a staggering 11 NBA Championships with the Boston Celtics between 1957-1969
column26: said: \\u201c[Wife] Jeannine & I are absolutely shocked to hear of the loss of one of my favorite people & one of the best basketball minds in the history of the game! Our hearts & prayers to Vanessa & his girls. \\u200b\\n\\nAmerican comedian and TV host Ellen DeGeneres said she is \\u201cstunned and saddened\\u201d by the news that basketball star Kobe Bryant has died in a helicopter crash.\\n\\nShe said on Twitter: \\u201cLike everyone
column27: I\\u2019m stunned and saddened by the news about Kobe Bryant. My heart is broken for his wife and family.\\u201d\\n\\nA moment of silence was observed prior to the Denver Nuggets game against the Houston Rockets
column28: which took place shortly after news of Bryant\\u2019s death broke
column29: with fans heard chanting Bryant\\u2019s name
column30: and a similar tribute took place at the NFL's Pro-Bowl game in Orlando.\\n\\nGolfing great Tiger Woods
column31: a lifelong Lakers fan who shared a close friendship with Bryant
column32: was informed of the news by his caddie midway through his final round at the PGA Tour Farmers Insurance Open.\\n\\nCher tweeted: \\u201cIt\\u2019s SO HARD To Deal With The Death Of a GREAT STAR
column33: Because We Feel As If We Knew Them Personally.Kobe Bryant Was a GREAT ATHLETE
column34: & All Of America Will Feel His Loss.\\u201d\\n\\nUsing emojis
column35: she said her heart \\u201cgoes out to all Kobe\\u2019s family
column37: fans\\u201d and that the world had lost a \\u201cbright light\\u201d.\\n\\nUS politician Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez paid tribute to Bryant and the other passengers of the helicopter.\\n\\nShe said on Twitter: \\\"Deeply shocked at the news of Kobe Bryant and four others lost today. Sending all my thoughts to their families and loved ones in this devastating moment.\\\"\\n\\nSinger Justin Bieber posted a photo of himself as a child with Bryant on Instagram.\\n\\nHe posted the accompanying caption: \\\"It can't be. You always encouraged me mamba. Gave me me some of the best quotes that we smile about to this day! Love you man!\\\"\\n\\n\\\"Continuing to move the game forward (at) King James
column38: \\\" Bryant wrote in his last tweet. \\\"Much respect my brother.\\\"\"

text: major us city sued over constitutional right to play music for tips a street musician is suing houston texas asserting he has a constitutional right to perform for tips
