column7: \"title\": \"Major U.S. city sued over 'constitutional right' to play music for tips\"
column9: Texas
column10: asserting he has a constitutional right to perform for tips.\\n\\n\\\"This First Amendment lawsuit challenges a city ordinance that unconstitutionally restricts musicians from busking (performing music in public for tips) on the streets of Houston
column11: \\\" the complaint in U.S. District Court in Houston states.\\n\\nThe plaintiff
column12: Anthony Barilla
column13: is a professional musician who wants to busk as an accordionist in Houston.\\n\\nTRENDING: On VIDEO: Stephanopoulos shuts down Sekulow with throat-cutting sign\\n\\nBut a city code prohibits playing music \\\"with the view of taking up [money]\\\" everywhere but a small part of the city known as the theater district
column14: the complaint states. And only after obtaining a permit that contains a \\\"heckler's veto.\\\"\\n\\nBarilla is defended by the Pacific Legal Foundation
column15: which said the musician is fighting the city's \\\"restriction on his ability to earn a living through freedom of expression.\\\"\\n\\n\\\"Tony Barilla's accordion represents the culmination of his skill
column17: and entrepreneurship. In addition to playing in a three-accordion cover band
column18: he writes
column19: composes
column20: and produces music for theater
column21: short films
column22: dance
column23: and radio. He\\u2019s currently writing and recording music for the nationally syndicated NPR podcast
column24: This American Life
column25: \\\" PLF said.\\n\\n\\\"Although Tony is already an accomplished accordionist
column26: he seeks opportunities to busk on the streets of his home
column27: Houston
column28: Texas. Busking is an important feature of urban life
column29: and for Tony it is a way of earning a living while refining his musical artistry and performance ability.\\\"\\n\\nAccepting tips while performing is outlawed throughout most of Houston's 665 square miles. The theater district
column30: where it is permitted under certain circumstances
column31: is only eight blocks long.\\n\\n\\\"Under the First Amendment \\u2026 the government cannot restrict Tony's freedom of expression by eliminating his financial incentive to perform. Nor can the government restrict speech based on content \\u2013 that is
column32: people can't use the government to shut down speech on public property that they simply don't like
column33: \\\" PLF said.\\n\\nThe complaint alleges the city \\\"restricts Tony's free speech rights in public places including sidewalks and streets.\\\"\\n\\nIt accuses the city of setting up \\\"content-based restrictions\\\" on speech
column34: contending it is not constitutionally allowed to \\\"restrict speech merely because it does not like it.\\\"\\n\\n\\\"Tony has been suffering and will continue to suffer substantial and irreparable harm unless Houston's busking restrictions including its permit requirement are declared unlawful and enjoined by this court
column35: \\\" the complaint charges.\"

text: houston mayor others help residents after deadly blast mayor sylvester turner on saturday walked through the impacted neighborhoods in northwest houston and spoke with residents who were cleaning up after fridays explosion
source: {\id\": \"mail--2020-01-26--Houston mayor
source_type: others help residents after deadly blast\"
column9: others help residents after deadly blast\"
column10: \"content\": \"Mayor Sylvester Turner on Saturday walked through the impacted neighborhoods in northwest Houston and spoke with residents who were cleaning up after Friday\\u2019s explosion. Cleanup and repair efforts continued Sunday.\\n\\n\\u201cThese people\\u2019s lives have been devastated by the Houston explosion. We are not going to forget about them
column11: \\u201d Turner said. The explosion happened about 4:30 a.m. Friday inside a building at Watson Grinding and Manufacturing
column12: which makes valves and provides thermal-spray coatings for equipment in various industries
column13: authorities said. Employees Frank Flores and Gerardo Castorena were killed.\\n\\nIn a statement released Saturday
column14: Castorena\\u2019s family said
column15: \\\"It's with a heavy heart that we had to say goodbye to a loving father
column17: brother
column18: and friend yesterday morning. We do ask for privacy as we grieve during this time. Thank you all to those for your kind words and support as we get through this difficult time.\\u201d\\n\\nAuthorities say an additional 20 people were injured \\u2014 two other warehouse workers and 18 others from neighboring homes and businesses. The explosion\\u2019s cause is being investigated. More than 200 homes in surrounding neighborhoods were damaged as the force of the blast shattered windows
column19: knocked down ceilings
column20: bent garage doors and moved some homes off their foundations.\\n\\nDozens of volunteers were out helping residents on Saturday. More than 80 of the volunteers were from Restore Houston
column21: a network of area churches dedicated to assisting families whose homes were damaged from flooding during Hurricane Harvey in 2017.\\n\\n\\u201cWe\\u2019ll be doing some work on homes
column22: boarding up windows
column24: but more importantly we\\u2019ll be loving on our neighbors and making sure they are aware that they are not alone in this
column25: \\u201d Josef Klam
column26: a pastor with Chapelwood United Methodist Church
column27: told the Houston Chronicle.\"
column28: \"author\": \"\"
column29: \"url\": \"https://www.mail.com/news/politics/9687992-houston-mayor-help-residents-deadly-blast.html\"
column30: \"published\": \"Sun
column33: \"collection_utc\": 1580085116}"
column34: News

column9: others help residents after deadly blast\"
column10: \"content\": \"Mayor Sylvester Turner on Saturday walked through the impacted neighborhoods in northwest Houston and spoke with residents who were cleaning up after Friday\\u2019s explosion. Cleanup and repair efforts continued Sunday.\\n\\n\\u201cThese people\\u2019s lives have been devastated by the Houston explosion. We are not going to forget about them
column11: \\u201d Turner said. The explosion happened about 4:30 a.m. Friday inside a building at Watson Grinding and Manufacturing
column12: which makes valves and provides thermal-spray coatings for equipment in various industries
column13: authorities said. Employees Frank Flores and Gerardo Castorena were killed.\\n\\nIn a statement released Saturday
column14: Castorena\\u2019s family said
column15: \\\"It's with a heavy heart that we had to say goodbye to a loving father
column17: brother
column18: and friend yesterday morning. We do ask for privacy as we grieve during this time. Thank you all to those for your kind words and support as we get through this difficult time.\\u201d\\n\\nAuthorities say an additional 20 people were injured \\u2014 two other warehouse workers and 18 others from neighboring homes and businesses. The explosion\\u2019s cause is being investigated. More than 200 homes in surrounding neighborhoods were damaged as the force of the blast shattered windows
column19: knocked down ceilings
column20: bent garage doors and moved some homes off their foundations.\\n\\nDozens of volunteers were out helping residents on Saturday. More than 80 of the volunteers were from Restore Houston
column21: a network of area churches dedicated to assisting families whose homes were damaged from flooding during Hurricane Harvey in 2017.\\n\\n\\u201cWe\\u2019ll be doing some work on homes
column22: boarding up windows
column24: but more importantly we\\u2019ll be loving on our neighbors and making sure they are aware that they are not alone in this
column25: \\u201d Josef Klam
column26: a pastor with Chapelwood United Methodist Church
column27: told the Houston Chronicle.\"

text: houston mayor others help residents after deadly blast houston ap  houstons mayor and others say they will work to provide assistance to residents whose homes were damaged after a massive explosion at a warehouse that killed two workers and injured 20 others
source: {\id\": \"usnews--2020-01-26--Houston Mayor
source_type: Others Help Residents After Deadly Blast\"
column9: Others Help Residents After Deadly Blast\"
column10: \"content\": \"HOUSTON (AP) \\u2014 Houston\\u2019s mayor and others say they will work to provide assistance to residents whose homes were damaged after a massive explosion at a warehouse that killed two workers and injured 20 others.\\n\\nMayor Sylvester Turner on Saturday walked through the impacted neighborhoods in northwest Houston and spoke with residents who were cleaning up after Friday\\u2019s explosion. Cleanup and repair efforts continued Sunday.\\n\\n\\u201cThese people\\u2019s lives have been devastated by the Houston explosion. We are not going to forget about them
column11: \\u201d Turner said.\\n\\nThe explosion happened about 4:30 a.m. Friday inside a building at Watson Grinding and Manufacturing
column12: which makes valves and provides thermal-spray coatings for equipment in various industries
column13: authorities said. Employees Frank Flores and Gerardo Castorena were killed.\\n\\nIn a statement released Saturday
column14: Castorena\\u2019s family said
column15: \\\"It's with a heavy heart that we had to say goodbye to a loving father
column17: brother
column18: and friend yesterday morning. We do ask for privacy as we grieve during this time. Thank you all to those for your kind words and support as we get through this difficult time.\\u201d\\n\\nAuthorities say an additional 20 people were injured \\u2014 two other warehouse workers and 18 others from neighboring homes and businesses. The explosion\\u2019s cause is being investigated.\\n\\nMore than 200 homes in surrounding neighborhoods were damaged as the force of the blast shattered windows
column19: knocked down ceilings
column20: bent garage doors and moved some homes off their foundations.\\n\\nMore than 80 of the volunteers were from Restore Houston
column21: a network of area churches dedicated to assisting families whose homes were damaged from flooding during Hurricane Harvey in 2017.\\n\\n\\u201cWe\\u2019ll be doing some work on homes
column22: boarding up windows
column24: but more importantly we\\u2019ll be loving on our neighbors and making sure they are aware that they are not alone in this
column25: \\u201d Josef Klam
column26: a pastor with Chapelwood United Methodist Church
column27: told the Houston Chronicle.\\n\\nCopyright 2020 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published
column28: broadcast
column29: rewritten or redistributed.\"

The explosion\\u2019s cause is being investigated.\\n\\nMore than 200 homes in surrounding neighborhoods were damaged as the force of the blast shattered windows

column20: bent garage doors and moved some homes off their foundations.\\n\\nMore than 80 of the volunteers were from Restore Houston

column10: \"content\": \"HOUSTON (AP) \\u2014 Houston\\u2019s mayor and others say they will work to provide assistance to residents whose homes were damaged after a massive explosion at a warehouse that killed two workers and injured 20 others.\\n\\nMayor Sylvester Turner on Saturday walked through the impacted neighborhoods in northwest Houston and spoke with residents who were cleaning up after Friday\\u2019s explosion. Cleanup and repair efforts continued Sunday.\\n\\n\\u201cThese people\\u2019s lives have been devastated by the Houston explosion. We are not going to forget about them
column11: \\u201d Turner said.\\n\\nThe explosion happened about 4:30 a.m. Friday inside a building at Watson Grinding and Manufacturing
column12: which makes valves and provides thermal-spray coatings for equipment in various industries
column13: authorities said. Employees Frank Flores and Gerardo Castorena were killed.\\n\\nIn a statement released Saturday
column14: Castorena\\u2019s family said
column15: \\\"It's with a heavy heart that we had to say goodbye to a loving father
column17: brother
column18: and friend yesterday morning. We do ask for privacy as we grieve during this time. Thank you all to those for your kind words and support as we get through this difficult time.\\u201d\\n\\nAuthorities say an additional 20 people were injured \\u2014 two other warehouse workers and 18 others from neighboring homes and businesses. The explosion\\u2019s cause is being investigated.\\n\\nMore than 200 homes in surrounding neighborhoods were damaged as the force of the blast shattered windows
column19: knocked down ceilings
column20: bent garage doors and moved some homes off their foundations.\\n\\nMore than 80 of the volunteers were from Restore Houston
column21: a network of area churches dedicated to assisting families whose homes were damaged from flooding during Hurricane Harvey in 2017.\\n\\n\\u201cWe\\u2019ll be doing some work on homes
column22: boarding up windows
column24: but more importantly we\\u2019ll be loving on our neighbors and making sure they are aware that they are not alone in this
column25: \\u201d Josef Klam
column26: a pastor with Chapelwood United Methodist Church
column27: told the Houston Chronicle.\\n\\nCopyright 2020 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published

column29: rewritten or redistributed.\"

text: kobe bryant nba legend dies in helicopter crash at age of 41 kobe bryant one of the greatest basketball players of all time has died in a helicopter crash
source: {\id\": \"theguardianuk--2020-01-26--Kobe Bryant: NBA legend dies in helicopter crash at age of 41\"
column7: \"title\": \"Kobe Bryant: NBA legend dies in helicopter crash at age of 41\"
column9: one of the greatest basketball players of all time
column10: has died in a helicopter crash. He was 41.\\n\\nBryant was on board the helicopter along with eight others when it crashed at 10am local time near Calabasas
column11: 30 miles north-west of downtown Los Angeles
column12: in foggy weather. The crash ignited brushfires
column13: making it hard for rescue crews to get close to the site. There were no reported survivors
column14: and although authorities did not confirm the identity of any of the victims
column15: Bryant\\u2019s 13-year-old daughter
column17: is also believed to have died in the crash. Bryant had lived in the area for most of his life and often used helicopters to beat Los Angeles\\u2019s heavy traffic.\\n\\n\\u201cWe received a call just before 10am this morning of an aircraft down in the Malibu area
column18: right off of Las Vergenes
column19: essentially Calabasas
column20: \\u201d Tony Imbrenda of the Los Angeles county fire department
column21: told reporters at the scene. \\u201cSome folks were out here mountain biking this morning
column22: they saw an aircraft in distress
column23: they went down into the hillside. This was a helicopter
column24: it\\u2019s been confirmed it was an S-76 Sikorsky helicopter and unfortunately there were no survivors.\\u201d\\n\\nThe Federal Aviation Administration and National Transportation Safety Board said they will investigate the accident.\\n\\nBryant\\u2019s talent was obvious from an early age
column25: and he was already attracting national attention while still in high school. Unlike most NBA players
column26: he went straight from school to the NBA
column27: foregoing a college career. He played his entire
column28: 20-year career with the Los Angeles Lakers
column29: where he won five championships with the team and was named an All-Star on 18 occasions. He retired in 2016 as the NBA\\u2019s third-highest all-time scorer. He also won gold medals with Team USA at the 2008 and 2012 Olympics.\\n\\n\\u201cThe NBA family is devastated by the tragic passing of Kobe Bryantand his daughter
column30: Gianna
column31: \\u201d the NBA commissioner
column33: said in a statement.\\n\\n\\n\\n\\u201cFor 20 seasons
column34: Kobe showed us what is possible when remarkable talent blends with an absolute devotion to winning. He was one of the most extraordinary players in the history of our game with accomplishments that are legendary: five NBA championships
column35: an NBA MVP award
column37: and two Olympic gold medals. But he will be remembered most for inspiring people around the world to pick up a basketball and compete to the very best of their ability.\\n\\n\\u201cHe was generous with the wisdom he acquired and saw it as his mission to share it with future generations of players
column38: taking special delight in passing down his love of the game to Gianna.\\u201d\\n\\nBryant moved into the media following his retirement and in 2018 he won an Oscar for best animated short for a film called Dear Basketball

column7: \"title\": \"France and Britain's Cold War: The Race to Zero Emissions\"
column8: \"content\": \"The long-running rivalry between France and Britain has entered a new era: who will decarbonise the fastest. As the UK government announced on June 11 that it had committed to a net zero emissions target for 2050
column9: the French parliament is currently working on a draft energy and climate bill that has the same target for 2050.\\n\\nIn both cases
column10: the net zero objective ramps up earlier targets. In France
column11: it would replace one set by a 2015 energy transition law
column12: which targeted a 75% cut in greenhouse-gas emissions by 2050 compared to 1990 levels. In the UK
column13: net zero for 2050 replaces a previous target of an 80% reduction over the same period; it was introduced in the law on June 12. The increased ambition is the result of advice from the UK\\u2019s Committee on Climate Change (CCC)
column14: the country\\u2019s independent advisory body.\\n\\nFrance and the UK are the largest countries so far to set such an ambitious objective in legislation. Sweden
column15: Denmark and Norway have already adopted the legal objective of carbon neutrality
column16: but with the use of international emissions-trading mechanisms.\\n\\nThe French project and the recommendation of the CCC in UK do not include this type of mechanism
column17: although the UK government announced it reserves the right to use credits. Other countries \\u2013 such as Ethiopia
column18: Costa Rica
column19: Bhutan
column20: Fiji Islands
column21: Iceland
column22: Marshall Islands and Portugal \\u2013 have also announced plans for carbon neutrality by 2050 in strategic documents but without legislative scope.\\n\\nThe 2018 report of the IPCC indicates that to stabilise global warming at 1.5\\u00b0C
column23: net emissions at the global scale must reach zero by 2050; and by 2070 for 2\\u00b0C.\\n\\nEmissions of other greenhouse gases must also be significantly reduced to maintain these trajectories. The CCC report also shows that neutrality of \\u201call greenhouse gases\\u201d by 2070 is compatible with the 1.5\\u00b0C trajectory. This means that the 2050 net zero emissions goal for all greenhouse gases is more ambitious than the global trajectory compatible with 1.5\\u00b0C warming.\\n\\nComparing emissions on both sides of the Channel\\n\\nFrance and the United Kingdom share many characteristics. They have similar populations
column24: comparable levels of development and their territorial greenhouse-gas emissions are similar \\u2013 7 tCO\\u2082 per inhabitant for the United Kingdom and 6.7 tCO\\u2082 per inhabitant for France in 2017.\\n\\nEmission trajectories since 1990 have been decreasing overall
column25: with a larger decrease for the UK from a higher level in 1990. This is mostly due to the transition away from coal-fired power plants for electricity
column26: as well as a significant catch-up in waste management.\\n\\nC. Guivarch and C. Le Qu\\u00e9r\\u00e9
column27: based on data from CITEPA (France) and BEIS (RU)
column28: Author provided\\n\\nEmissions from the industrial sector are decreasing significantly and similarly in both countries. According to CCC\\u2019s analysis
column29: this decline in the United Kingdom can be explained by changes in economic structure
column30: improved energy efficiency and a reduction in the carbon intensity of the energy mix.\\n\\nC. Guivarch and C. Le Qu\\u00e9r\\u00e9
column31: based on data from CITEPA (France) and BEIS (RU)
column32: Author provided\\n\\nEmissions from the building sector have declined over the past 10 years in both countries
column33: with larger decreases in the United Kingdom. In contrast
column34: emissions from the transport sector have stagnated in both countries
column35: with a slight decrease in the United Kingdom and an increase in France since 1990.\\n\\nHowever
column36: important differences exist in agriculture and carbon sinks. Agriculture is economically more important in France
column37: emitting twice as much carbon much as in the United Kingdom. Carbon sinks
column38: which are largely based on the increase in carbon stored in forests
column39: are also more significant in France. Emissions reduction in both sectors are comparable.\\n\\nC. Guivarch and C. Le Qu\\u00e9r\\u00e9
column40: based on data from CITEPA (France) and BEIS (RU)
column41: Author provided\\n\\nOne important difference concerns emissions from international transport. Aviation and maritime transport emissions are not included in the reporting to the United Nations under the Paris Agreement. The UK\\u2019s net zero objective includes these emissions
column42: while France\\u2019s current draft energy bill does not.\\n\\nIf the other sectors follow the projected reduction pathways
column43: emissions from aviation
column44: which are relatively low for the time being
column45: will be responsible for the majority of remaining emissions in 2050. They will therefore have to be offset by carbon sinks or other CO extraction mechanisms
column46: requiring a significant increase in the number of sinks (see figure below
column47: based on data from the United Kingdomand France).\\n\\nC. Guivarch and C. Le Qu\\u00e9r\\u00e9
column48: based on data from CITEPA (France) and BEIS (RU)
column49: Author provided \\n\\n\\n\\nIn their 2050 net zero objectives
column50: France and the United Kingdom do not include so-called \\u201cimported\\u201d emissions \\u2013 those associated with consuming products and services from abroad.\\n\\nIncluding these imported emissions
column51: the carbon footprints of both nations reach 11 tCO\\u2082/inhabitant/year for France and 11.9 tCO\\u2082/inhabitant/year for the United Kingdom.\\n\\nC. Guivarch and C. Le Qu\\u00e9r\\u00e9
column52: based on data from CITEPA (France) and BEIS (RU)
column53: Author provided\\n\\nAfter accounting for products consumed abroad (\\u201cexported\\u201d emissions)
column54: emissions from the trade balance are very high and have risen since the mid-1990s (see figure opposite) with a possible slowdown since 2005 in the United Kingdom and since 2011 in France. These emissions are difficult to control
column55: they are nevertheless the responsibility of consumers.\\n\\nWhile France\\u2019s draft energy and climate law states that these emissions must be controlled
column56: it gives no quantitative targets. In the UK
column57: the CCC recommendation is that these emissions should decline in response to certain efficiency measures
column58: but recognizes that these emissions can only be reduced to zero when global emissions reach this threshold.\\n\\nThe United Kingdom has managed to rapidly reduce its emissions over the past decade
column59: which are now close to the French level. This rapid decrease was recommended and monitored by the Committee on Climate Change
column60: which has prioritized the decarbonisation of electricity production that underlies that of other sectors. Today
column61: both countries are at a point where emissions must decrease rapidly in the coming decades to reach their net zero targets by 2050.\\n\\nA shared challenge is initiating and accelerating the transition in sectors that are tough to decarbonise because
column62: compared with the energy sector
column63: emissions are more diffuse \\u2013 particularly transport and buildings.\\n\\nThe Haut Conseil pour le Climat
column64: of which we are both members
column65: was created in late 2018 and directly inspired by the UK CCC. There is no magic policy package that will lead nations to net zero emissions in 2050. The UK example demonstrates
column66: and France acknowledges
column67: the need for an independent advisory group that is focused on the long-term to support and guide the transition in the coming decades.\\n\\nThe French Haut Conseil will assess the implementation of France\\u2019s national low-carbon strategy and propose course corrections where necessary
column68: while taking into account the socio-economic impacts of the transition on households and businesses as well as environmental impacts. Its first report will be made public on June 25.\\n\\nC\\u00e9line Guivarch is part of the team of authors of the 6th IPCC report. She is a member of the French High Council for Climate Change. C\\u00e9line Guivarch has received funding from the European Commission
column69: the Ministry of Ecological and Solidarity Transition
column70: the French Environment and Energy Management Agency
column71: the French Environment and Energy Management Agency
column76: the \\\"Mod\\u00e9lisation prospective pour le d\\u00e9veloppement durable\\\" chair and the Institut pour la mobilit\\u00e9 durable. It is a member of the \\\"Weather and Climate\\\" association.\\n\\nCorinne Le Qu\\u00e9r\\u00e9 is President of the High Council for Climate Change. For her research on the carbon cycle
column77: she has received funding from the European Commission
column78: the Royal Society of the United Kingdom
column79: the Natural Environment Research Council (UK).\\n\\nTheir article first appeared in The Conversation in June 2019.\"

column7: \"title\": \"France and Britain's Cold War: The Race to Zero Emissions\"
column8: \"content\": \"The long-running rivalry between France and Britain has entered a new era: who will decarbonise the fastest. As the UK government announced on June 11 that it had committed to a net zero emissions target for 2050
column9: the French parliament is currently working on a draft energy and climate bill that has the same target for 2050.\\n\\nIn both cases
column10: the net zero objective ramps up earlier targets. In France
column11: it would replace one set by a 2015 energy transition law
column12: which targeted a 75% cut in greenhouse-gas emissions by 2050 compared to 1990 levels. In the UK
column13: net zero for 2050 replaces a previous target of an 80% reduction over the same period; it was introduced in the law on June 12. The increased ambition is the result of advice from the UK\\u2019s Committee on Climate Change (CCC)
column14: the country\\u2019s independent advisory body.\\n\\nFrance and the UK are the largest countries so far to set such an ambitious objective in legislation. Sweden
column15: Denmark and Norway have already adopted the legal objective of carbon neutrality
column16: but with the use of international emissions-trading mechanisms.\\n\\nThe French project and the recommendation of the CCC in UK do not include this type of mechanism
column17: although the UK government announced it reserves the right to use credits. Other countries \\u2013 such as Ethiopia
column18: Costa Rica
column19: Bhutan
column20: Fiji Islands
column21: Iceland
column22: Marshall Islands and Portugal \\u2013 have also announced plans for carbon neutrality by 2050 in strategic documents but without legislative scope.\\n\\nThe 2018 report of the IPCC indicates that to stabilise global warming at 1.5\\u00b0C
column23: net emissions at the global scale must reach zero by 2050; and by 2070 for 2\\u00b0C.\\n\\nEmissions of other greenhouse gases must also be significantly reduced to maintain these trajectories. The CCC report also shows that neutrality of \\u201call greenhouse gases\\u201d by 2070 is compatible with the 1.5\\u00b0C trajectory. This means that the 2050 net zero emissions goal for all greenhouse gases is more ambitious than the global trajectory compatible with 1.5\\u00b0C warming.\\n\\nComparing emissions on both sides of the Channel\\n\\nFrance and the United Kingdom share many characteristics. They have similar populations
column24: comparable levels of development and their territorial greenhouse-gas emissions are similar \\u2013 7 tCO\\u2082 per inhabitant for the United Kingdom and 6.7 tCO\\u2082 per inhabitant for France in 2017.\\n\\nEmission trajectories since 1990 have been decreasing overall
column25: with a larger decrease for the UK from a higher level in 1990. This is mostly due to the transition away from coal-fired power plants for electricity
column26: as well as a significant catch-up in waste management.\\n\\nC. Guivarch and C. Le Qu\\u00e9r\\u00e9

source: {\id\": \"nationalinterest--2020-01-27--France and Britain's Cold War: The Race to Zero Emissions\"
column7: \"title\": \"France and Britain's Cold War: The Race to Zero Emissions\"
column8: \"content\": \"The long-running rivalry between France and Britain has entered a new era: who will decarbonise the fastest. As the UK government announced on June 11 that it had committed to a net zero emissions target for 2050
column9: the French parliament is currently working on a draft energy and climate bill that has the same target for 2050.\\n\\nIn both cases
column10: the net zero objective ramps up earlier targets. In France
column11: it would replace one set by a 2015 energy transition law
column12: which targeted a 75% cut in greenhouse-gas emissions by 2050 compared to 1990 levels. In the UK
column13: net zero for 2050 replaces a previous target of an 80% reduction over the same period; it was introduced in the law on June 12. The increased ambition is the result of advice from the UK\\u2019s Committee on Climate Change (CCC)
column14: the country\\u2019s independent advisory body.\\n\\nFrance and the UK are the largest countries so far to set such an ambitious objective in legislation. Sweden
column15: Denmark and Norway have already adopted the legal objective of carbon neutrality
column16: but with the use of international emissions-trading mechanisms.\\n\\nThe French project and the recommendation of the CCC in UK do not include this type of mechanism
column17: although the UK government announced it reserves the right to use credits. Other countries \\u2013 such as Ethiopia
column18: Costa Rica
column19: Bhutan
column20: Fiji Islands
column21: Iceland
column22: Marshall Islands and Portugal \\u2013 have also announced plans for carbon neutrality by 2050 in strategic documents but without legislative scope.\\n\\nThe 2018 report of the IPCC indicates that to stabilise global warming at 1.5\\u00b0C
column23: net emissions at the global scale must reach zero by 2050; and by 2070 for 2\\u00b0C.\\n\\nEmissions of other greenhouse gases must also be significantly reduced to maintain these trajectories. The CCC report also shows that neutrality of \\u201call greenhouse gases\\u201d by 2070 is compatible with the 1.5\\u00b0C trajectory. This means that the 2050 net zero emissions goal for all greenhouse gases is more ambitious than the global trajectory compatible with 1.5\\u00b0C warming.\\n\\nComparing emissions on both sides of the Channel\\n\\nFrance and the United Kingdom share many characteristics. They have similar populations
column24: comparable levels of development and their territorial greenhouse-gas emissions are similar \\u2013 7 tCO\\u2082 per inhabitant for the United Kingdom and 6.7 tCO\\u2082 per inhabitant for France in 2017.\\n\\nEmission trajectories since 1990 have been decreasing overall
column25: with a larger decrease for the UK from a higher level in 1990. This is mostly due to the transition away from coal-fired power plants for electricity
column26: as well as a significant catch-up in waste management.\\n\\nC. Guivarch and C. Le Qu\\u00e9r\\u00e9
column27: based on data from CITEPA (France) and BEIS (RU)
column28: Author provided\\n\\nEmissions from the industrial sector are decreasing significantly and similarly in both countries. According to CCC\\u2019s analysis
column29: this decline in the United Kingdom can be explained by changes in economic structure
column30: improved energy efficiency and a reduction in the carbon intensity of the energy mix.\\n\\nC. Guivarch and C. Le Qu\\u00e9r\\u00e9
column31: based on data from CITEPA (France) and BEIS (RU)
column32: Author provided\\n\\nEmissions from the building sector have declined over the past 10 years in both countries
column33: with larger decreases in the United Kingdom. In contrast
column34: emissions from the transport sector have stagnated in both countries
column35: with a slight decrease in the United Kingdom and an increase in France since 1990.\\n\\nHowever
column36: important differences exist in agriculture and carbon sinks. Agriculture is economically more important in France
column37: emitting twice as much carbon much as in the United Kingdom. Carbon sinks
column38: which are largely based on the increase in carbon stored in forests
column39: are also more significant in France. Emissions reduction in both sectors are comparable.\\n\\nC. Guivarch and C. Le Qu\\u00e9r\\u00e9
column40: based on data from CITEPA (France) and BEIS (RU)
column41: Author provided\\n\\nOne important difference concerns emissions from international transport. Aviation and maritime transport emissions are not included in the reporting to the United Nations under the Paris Agreement. The UK\\u2019s net zero objective includes these emissions
column42: while France\\u2019s current draft energy bill does not.\\n\\nIf the other sectors follow the projected reduction pathways
column43: emissions from aviation
column44: which are relatively low for the time being
column45: will be responsible for the majority of remaining emissions in 2050. They will therefore have to be offset by carbon sinks or other CO extraction mechanisms
column46: requiring a significant increase in the number of sinks (see figure below
column47: based on data from the United Kingdomand France).\\n\\nC. Guivarch and C. Le Qu\\u00e9r\\u00e9
column48: based on data from CITEPA (France) and BEIS (RU)
column49: Author provided \\n\\n\\n\\nIn their 2050 net zero objectives
column50: France and the United Kingdom do not include so-called \\u201cimported\\u201d emissions \\u2013 those associated with consuming products and services from abroad.\\n\\nIncluding these imported emissions
column51: the carbon footprints of both nations reach 11 tCO\\u2082/inhabitant/year for France and 11.9 tCO\\u2082/inhabitant/year for the United Kingdom.\\n\\nC. Guivarch and C. Le Qu\\u00e9r\\u00e9
column52: based on data from CITEPA (France) and BEIS (RU)
column53: Author provided\\n\\nAfter accounting for products consumed abroad (\\u201cexported\\u201d emissions)
column54: emissions from the trade balance are very high and have risen since the mid-1990s (see figure opposite) with a possible slowdown since 2005 in the United Kingdom and since 2011 in France. These emissions are difficult to control
column55: they are nevertheless the responsibility of consumers.\\n\\nWhile France\\u2019s draft energy and climate law states that these emissions must be controlled
column56: it gives no quantitative targets. In the UK
column57: the CCC recommendation is that these emissions should decline in response to certain efficiency measures
column58: but recognizes that these emissions can only be reduced to zero when global emissions reach this threshold.\\n\\nThe United Kingdom has managed to rapidly reduce its emissions over the past decade
column59: which are now close to the French level. This rapid decrease was recommended and monitored by the Committee on Climate Change
column60: which has prioritized the decarbonisation of electricity production that underlies that of other sectors. Today
column61: both countries are at a point where emissions must decrease rapidly in the coming decades to reach their net zero targets by 2050.\\n\\nA shared challenge is initiating and accelerating the transition in sectors that are tough to decarbonise because
column62: compared with the energy sector
column63: emissions are more diffuse \\u2013 particularly transport and buildings.\\n\\nThe Haut Conseil pour le Climat
column64: of which we are both members
column65: was created in late 2018 and directly inspired by the UK CCC. There is no magic policy package that will lead nations to net zero emissions in 2050. The UK example demonstrates
column66: and France acknowledges
column67: the need for an independent advisory group that is focused on the long-term to support and guide the transition in the coming decades.\\n\\nThe French Haut Conseil will assess the implementation of France\\u2019s national low-carbon strategy and propose course corrections where necessary
column68: while taking into account the socio-economic impacts of the transition on households and businesses as well as environmental impacts. Its first report will be made public on June 25.\\n\\nC\\u00e9line Guivarch is part of the team of authors of the 6th IPCC report. She is a member of the French High Council for Climate Change. C\\u00e9line Guivarch has received funding from the European Commission
column69: the Ministry of Ecological and Solidarity Transition
column70: the French Environment and Energy Management Agency
column71: the French Environment and Energy Management Agency
column76: the \\\"Mod\\u00e9lisation prospective pour le d\\u00e9veloppement durable\\\" chair and the Institut pour la mobilit\\u00e9 durable. It is a member of the \\\"Weather and Climate\\\" association.\\n\\nCorinne Le Qu\\u00e9r\\u00e9 is President of the High Council for Climate Change. For her research on the carbon cycle
column77: she has received funding from the European Commission
column78: the Royal Society of the United Kingdom
column79: the Natural Environment Research Council (UK).\\n\\nTheir article first appeared in The Conversation in June 2019.\"

column7: \"title\": \"France and Britain's Cold War: The Race to Zero Emissions\"
column8: \"content\": \"The long-running rivalry between France and Britain has entered a new era: who will decarbonise the fastest. As the UK government announced on June 11 that it had committed to a net zero emissions target for 2050
column9: the French parliament is currently working on a draft energy and climate bill that has the same target for 2050.\\n\\nIn both cases
column10: the net zero objective ramps up earlier targets. In France
column11: it would replace one set by a 2015 energy transition law
column12: which targeted a 75% cut in greenhouse-gas emissions by 2050 compared to 1990 levels. In the UK
column13: net zero for 2050 replaces a previous target of an 80% reduction over the same period; it was introduced in the law on June 12. The increased ambition is the result of advice from the UK\\u2019s Committee on Climate Change (CCC)
column14: the country\\u2019s independent advisory body.\\n\\nFrance and the UK are the largest countries so far to set such an ambitious objective in legislation. Sweden
column15: Denmark and Norway have already adopted the legal objective of carbon neutrality
column16: but with the use of international emissions-trading mechanisms.\\n\\nThe French project and the recommendation of the CCC in UK do not include this type of mechanism
column17: although the UK government announced it reserves the right to use credits. Other countries \\u2013 such as Ethiopia
column18: Costa Rica
column19: Bhutan
column20: Fiji Islands
column21: Iceland
column22: Marshall Islands and Portugal \\u2013 have also announced plans for carbon neutrality by 2050 in strategic documents but without legislative scope.\\n\\nThe 2018 report of the IPCC indicates that to stabilise global warming at 1.5\\u00b0C
column23: net emissions at the global scale must reach zero by 2050; and by 2070 for 2\\u00b0C.\\n\\nEmissions of other greenhouse gases must also be significantly reduced to maintain these trajectories. The CCC report also shows that neutrality of \\u201call greenhouse gases\\u201d by 2070 is compatible with the 1.5\\u00b0C trajectory. This means that the 2050 net zero emissions goal for all greenhouse gases is more ambitious than the global trajectory compatible with 1.5\\u00b0C warming.\\n\\nComparing emissions on both sides of the Channel\\n\\nFrance and the United Kingdom share many characteristics. They have similar populations
column24: comparable levels of development and their territorial greenhouse-gas emissions are similar \\u2013 7 tCO\\u2082 per inhabitant for the United Kingdom and 6.7 tCO\\u2082 per inhabitant for France in 2017.\\n\\nEmission trajectories since 1990 have been decreasing overall
column25: with a larger decrease for the UK from a higher level in 1990. This is mostly due to the transition away from coal-fired power plants for electricity
column26: as well as a significant catch-up in waste management.\\n\\nC. Guivarch and C. Le Qu\\u00e9r\\u00e9
column27: based on data from CITEPA (France) and BEIS (RU)
column28: Author provided\\n\\nEmissions from the industrial sector are decreasing significantly and similarly in both countries. According to CCC\\u2019s analysis
column29: this decline in the United Kingdom can be explained by changes in economic structure
column30: improved energy efficiency and a reduction in the carbon intensity of the energy mix.\\n\\nC. Guivarch and C. Le Qu\\u00e9r\\u00e9
column31: based on data from CITEPA (France) and BEIS (RU)
column32: Author provided\\n\\nEmissions from the building sector have declined over the past 10 years in both countries
column33: with larger decreases in the United Kingdom. In contrast
column34: emissions from the transport sector have stagnated in both countries
column35: with a slight decrease in the United Kingdom and an increase in France since 1990.\\n\\nHowever
column36: important differences exist in agriculture and carbon sinks. Agriculture is economically more important in France
column37: emitting twice as much carbon much as in the United Kingdom. Carbon sinks
column38: which are largely based on the increase in carbon stored in forests
column39: are also more significant in France. Emissions reduction in both sectors are comparable.\\n\\nC. Guivarch and C. Le Qu\\u00e9r\\u00e9
column40: based on data from CITEPA (France) and BEIS (RU)

column42: while France\\u2019s current draft energy bill does not.\\n\\nIf the other sectors follow the projected reduction pathways

column7: \"title\": \"This Photo Is How an Empire Died (And How the U.S. Navy Crushed Japan)\"
column8: \"content\": \"Key Point: This battle changed it all.\\n\\nFounding German chancellor Otto von Bismarck was not a funny guy. As a rule
column9: in fact
column10: Bismarck was downright grim. He glowers at us from eternity. Once in awhile
column11: though
column12: the Iron Chancellor came out with a jest worthy of the great Yogi Berra\\u2014as when he reputedly proclaimed that Providence smiles on \\u201cfools
column13: drunkards
column14: and the United States of America.\\u201d Foolish besotted \\u2018Mercans must be triply blessed.\\n\\nYet Providence seldom does it all. It furnishes opportunity perchance. Individuals must grab and exploit opportunities fortune\\u2019s favor deigns to bestow on them.\\n\\nNever was this truer than June 1942
column15: when U.S. Navy and Imperial Japanese Navy (IJN) aircraft-carrier task forces met in battle off Midway Island
column16: an atoll northwest of Hawaii. Hollywood essays a rare look at naval history this weekend with the release of director Roland Emmerich\\u2019s Midway
column17: the first cinematic account of this epic clash since the 1970s. Not having seen the film yet
column18: I can neither praise its wholesome goodness nor damn its failings.\\n\\nThere remains plenty to say about the encounter
column19: regardless of how well Hollywood did its work. Fortune granted the USA its favor at Midway
column20: as Bismarck might have prophesied. But it was sound doctrine and strategy
column21: entrepreneurship among naval aviators
column22: and shrewd senior leadership that positioned the U.S. Pacific Fleet to harvest the opportunities placed before it. And harvest them the navy did. By the time the guns
column24: and torpedoes fell silent the Kid\\u014d Butai\\u00ad\\u00ad\\u2014the carrier striking fleet that had pounded Pearl Harbor six months before\\u2014adorned the Pacific seafloor.\\n\\nHistorian Craig Symonds pronounces Midway \\u201cthe most complete naval victory\\u201d since 1805
column25: when Lord Horatio Nelson\\u2019s Royal Navy swept the combined French and Spanish fleets from the briny main at Trafalgar. Was it a \\u201cdecisive\\u201d victory as well as complete? Opinions vary. How to define that word commonly provokes one of those scholarly debates that\\u2019s so envenomed because the stakes are so small. Some scholars of martial affairs insist that a decisive battle must lead directly to peace in fairly short order. It must decide the outcome of the war as a whole in order to qualify.\\n\\nThat\\u2019s a mighty constricted definition. To its purveyors we might say
column26: with Coach Lee Corso\\u2014this being college football season\\u2014not so fast
column27: my friend! And hazard a contrary view
column28: as Corso does when picking winners and losers on game day.\\n\\nThe classics of strategy divulge no concrete definition. Carl von Clausewitz comes closest in On War

column30: and it did decide the fate of Japan\\u2019s effort to rig a \\u201cribbon defense

column32: stretching from northerly island strongholds in the Aleutians through Midway at the ribbon\\u2019s midpoint through fastnesses farther south.\\n\\nAnd it did decide whether Tokyo would accomplish the goals for which it went to war. Answer on all counts: no. Midway reversed the flow of war in the Pacific from east to west
column33: and operations kept flowing westerly until ultimate Allied victory in 1945. Sounds decisive to me\\u2014much as Trafalgar decided who would rule the sea during the Napoleonic Wars. Nelson\\u2019s clean sweep may not have led directly or speedily to peace
column34: but it was a crucial enabler. It was a factor indispensable to the eventual outcome
column35: even though the little emperor didn\\u2019t meet his Waterloo for another decade.\\n\\nAnd opportunism\\u2014in particular the opportunism of Rear Admiral Raymond J. Spruance
column37: built around the flattops USS Enterprise and Hornet\\u2014helped the U.S. Navy reap the fruits of decisive battle. According to Samuel Eliot Morison
column38: the dean of World War II naval historians
column39: Spruance displayed \\u201cthe very highest quality of tactical wisdom
column40: the power to seize opportunities.\\u201d And although Spruance was a surface-ship officer in charge of naval aviation assets
column41: he had the spine to overrule professional aviators when circumstances warranted.\\n\\nPacific Fleet boss Admiral Chester Nimitz afforded Spruance and Rear Admiral Frank Jack Fletcher\\u2014who headed up Task Force 17
column43: and was assigned overall tactical command\\u2014ample leeway to shape their high-seas fate. Nimitz instructed them to conduct themselves by \\u201cthe principle of calculated risk\\u201d at Midway. By that he meant avoiding \\u201cexposure of your force to attack by superior enemy forces without good prospect of inflicting . . . greater damage on the enemy.\\u201d\\n\\nHis directive made strategic sense. Both combatants had committed all of their deployable fleet carriers to action at Midway. The IJN enjoyed a 4-3 numerical edge
column44: yet it was Nimitz who had the luxury of risking his carriers. They were replaceable where Japan\\u2019s were not. Nimitz presided over a remnant of the prewar Pacific Fleet. He knew that a bigger
column45: better U.S. Navy\\u2014including a brand-new class of fleet carriers
column46: the Essex class\\u2014was building in shipyards back home and would make its way to the Pacific Ocean starting in 1943. With only a fraction of American industrial capacity
column47: Japan could scarcely regenerate naval strength depleted in action. America could redeem its losses and then some; Japan would struggle to sustain itself.\\n\\nIf you have a spare weapon in the armory\\u2014or soon will\\u2014you may as well risk the one you have.\\n\\nAdmiral Spruance wielded Task Force 16 to good effect. Around daybreak on June 4 a Midway-based patrol plane reported sighting two IJN carriers steaming southeast toward the island. The American fleet had taken station to Midway\\u2019s northeast in hopes of mounting an ambush from an unexpected quarter

column51: Captain Miles Browning
column52: rightly surmised that Admiral Ch\\u016bichi Nagumo
column54: meant to bombard Midway and its U.S. Marine garrison.\\n\\nThey also suspected that Nagumo assumed no U.S. carriers would be in the vicinity. After all
column55: a diversionary force had staged attacks in the Aleutian Islands
column56: and top IJN commanders believed Nimitz would have dispatched the Pacific Fleet to intervene. Nagumo
column58: was conflicted when scout planes reported the presence of U.S. carriers: should he rearm the Kid\\u014d Butai\\u00ad\\u00ad\\u2019s warplanes with torpedoes to assail enemy shipping
column59: or keep loading them with bombs to execute subsequent raids against Midway?\\n\\nSpruance and Browning timed their launches to coincide with times of maximum flux in the Japanese fleet\\u2019s recovery and launch cycle\\u2014and to exploit Nagumo\\u2019s indecision. Carrier crews trying to refuel and arm warplanes are busy with other duties than self-defense. They\\u2019re also handling explosives and flammable liquids in parts of the ship vulnerable to bomb blasts.\\n\\nFor all that
column60: the American air attacks were no masterpiece of massing firepower at the decisive place and time for mass impact. In mid-morning Hornet and Enterprise torpedo-bombers went in low
column61: and broke themselves against the curtain of IJN anti-aircraft fire as well as Zeke fighters swooping overhead. While Japanese defenders concentrated their energies down low
column62: Enterprise and then Yorktown dive-bombers arrived overhead. They pounced on the enemy flattops from high altitude
column63: setting three of four ablaze within six minutes. Hiryu
column65: struck back successfully at Yorktown\\u2014only to be dispatched itself late that afternoon.\\n\\nThe Imperial Japanese Navy thus lost four of the Kid\\u014d Butai\\u00ad\\u00ad\\u2019s four fleet carriers in a day (two others damaged previously remained at home under repair and would return to action later in the war)

column72: and then proceed on their route en masse. In the process the first aircraft to launch would orbit overhead\\u2014and waste precious fuel while the rest of the group assembled.\\n\\nThe Hornet air wing conducted a deferred departure on the morning of June 4 at Browning\\u2019s direction. When the staff radio intelligence officer reported intercepting a Japanese scout plane\\u2019s transmission reporting the task force\\u2019s whereabouts
column76: \\u201cenough was enough.\\u201d He had the flagship signal to Enterprise dive-bomber squadrons circling overhead: \\u201cproceed on mission assigned.\\u201d In other words
column77: do not dawdle. Get aloft and proceed along your way. Spruance overrode procedures. That\\u2019s why the air wings attacked in fragmentary fashion\\u2014a drawback in combat\\u2014but it helped the bomber squadrons conserve fuel they would need to search out and attack the Japanese flattops. \\u201cIt was the right decision
column79: even though it cost the Americans in terms of coordinated action.\"

Opinions vary. How to define that word commonly provokes one of those scholarly debates that\\u2019s so envenomed because the stakes are so small. Some scholars of martial affairs insist that a decisive battle must lead directly to peace in fairly short order. It must decide the outcome of the war as a whole in order to qualify.\\n\\nThat\\u2019s a mighty constricted definition. To its purveyors we might say

column33: and operations kept flowing westerly until ultimate Allied victory in 1945. Sounds decisive to me\\u2014much as Trafalgar decided who would rule the sea during the Napoleonic Wars. Nelson\\u2019s clean sweep may not have led directly or speedily to peace

column38: the dean of World War II naval historians
column39: Spruance displayed \\u201cthe very highest quality of tactical wisdom
column40: the power to seize opportunities.\\u201d And although Spruance was a surface-ship officer in charge of naval aviation assets
column41: he had the spine to overrule professional aviators when circumstances warranted.\\n\\nPacific Fleet boss Admiral Chester Nimitz afforded Spruance and Rear Admiral Frank Jack Fletcher\\u2014who headed up Task Force 17
column43: and was assigned overall tactical command\\u2014ample leeway to shape their high-seas fate. Nimitz instructed them to conduct themselves by \\u201cthe principle of calculated risk\\u201d at Midway. By that he meant avoiding \\u201cexposure of your force to attack by superior enemy forces without good prospect of inflicting . . . greater damage on the enemy.\\u201d\\n\\nHis directive made strategic sense. Both combatants had committed all of their deployable fleet carriers to action at Midway. The IJN enjoyed a 4-3 numerical edge
column44: yet it was Nimitz who had the luxury of risking his carriers. They were replaceable where Japan\\u2019s were not. Nimitz presided over a remnant of the prewar Pacific Fleet. He knew that a bigger
column45: better U.S. Navy\\u2014including a brand-new class of fleet carriers
column46: the Essex class\\u2014was building in shipyards back home and would make its way to the Pacific Ocean starting in 1943. With only a fraction of American industrial capacity
column47: Japan could scarcely regenerate naval strength depleted in action. America could redeem its losses and then some; Japan would struggle to sustain itself.\\n\\nIf you have a spare weapon in the armory\\u2014or soon will\\u2014you may as well risk the one you have.\\n\\nAdmiral Spruance wielded Task Force 16 to good effect. Around daybreak on June 4 a Midway-based patrol plane reported sighting two IJN carriers steaming southeast toward the island. The American fleet had taken station to Midway\\u2019s northeast in hopes of mounting an ambush from an unexpected quarter

column59: or keep loading them with bombs to execute subsequent raids against Midway?\\n\\nSpruance and Browning timed their launches to coincide with times of maximum flux in the Japanese fleet\\u2019s recovery and launch cycle\\u2014and to exploit Nagumo\\u2019s indecision. They\\u2019re also handling explosives and flammable liquids in parts of the ship vulnerable to bomb blasts.\\n\\nFor all that
column60: the American air attacks were no masterpiece of massing firepower at the decisive place and time for mass impact. In mid-morning Hornet and Enterprise torpedo-bombers went in low

When the staff radio intelligence officer reported intercepting a Japanese scout plane\\u2019s transmission reporting the task force\\u2019s whereabouts

column77: do not dawdle. Get aloft and proceed along your way. Spruance overrode procedures. Some scholars of martial affairs insist that a decisive battle must lead directly to peace in fairly short order. It must decide the outcome of the war as a whole in order to qualify.\\n\\nThat\\u2019s a mighty constricted definition. To its purveyors we might say

column43: and was assigned overall tactical command\\u2014ample leeway to shape their high-seas fate. Nimitz instructed them to conduct themselves by \\u201cthe principle of calculated risk\\u201d at Midway. By that he meant avoiding \\u201cexposure of your force to attack by superior enemy forces without good prospect of inflicting . . . greater damage on the enemy.\\u201d\\n\\nHis directive made strategic sense. Both combatants had committed all of their deployable fleet carriers to action at Midway. The IJN enjoyed a 4-3 numerical edge
column44: yet it was Nimitz who had the luxury of risking his carriers. They were replaceable where Japan\\u2019s were not. Nimitz presided over a remnant of the prewar Pacific Fleet. He knew that a bigger
column45: better U.S. Navy\\u2014including a brand-new class of fleet carriers
column46: the Essex class\\u2014was building in shipyards back home and would make its way to the Pacific Ocean starting in 1943. With only a fraction of American industrial capacity
column47: Japan could scarcely regenerate naval strength depleted in action. America could redeem its losses and then some; Japan would struggle to sustain itself.\\n\\nIf you have a spare weapon in the armory\\u2014or soon will\\u2014you may as well risk the one you have.\\n\\nAdmiral Spruance wielded Task Force 16 to good effect. Around daybreak on June 4 a Midway-based patrol plane reported sighting two IJN carriers steaming southeast toward the island. column40: the power to seize opportunities.\\u201d And although Spruance was a surface-ship officer in charge of naval aviation assets

column43: and was assigned overall tactical command\\u2014ample leeway to shape their high-seas fate. Nimitz instructed them to conduct themselves by \\u201cthe principle of calculated risk\\u201d at Midway. By that he meant avoiding \\u201cexposure of your force to attack by superior enemy forces without good prospect of inflicting . . . greater damage on the enemy.\\u201d\\n\\nHis directive made strategic sense. Both combatants had committed all of their deployable fleet carriers to action at Midway. The IJN enjoyed a 4-3 numerical edge
column44: yet it was Nimitz who had the luxury of risking his carriers. They were replaceable where Japan\\u2019s were not. Nimitz presided over a remnant of the prewar Pacific Fleet. He knew that a bigger
column45: better U.S. Navy\\u2014including a brand-new class of fleet carriers
column46: the Essex class\\u2014was building in shipyards back home and would make its way to the Pacific Ocean starting in 1943. With only a fraction of American industrial capacity
column47: Japan could scarcely regenerate naval strength depleted in action. America could redeem its losses and then some; Japan would struggle to sustain itself.\\n\\nIf you have a spare weapon in the armory\\u2014or soon will\\u2014you may as well risk the one you have.\\n\\nAdmiral Spruance wielded Task Force 16 to good effect. Around daybreak on June 4 a Midway-based patrol plane reported sighting two IJN carriers steaming southeast toward the island. column58: was conflicted when scout planes reported the presence of U.S. carriers: should he rearm the Kid\\u014d Butai\\u00ad\\u00ad\\u2019s warplanes with torpedoes to assail enemy shipping
column59: or keep loading them with bombs to execute subsequent raids against Midway?\\n\\nSpruance and Browning timed their launches to coincide with times of maximum flux in the Japanese fleet\\u2019s recovery and launch cycle\\u2014and to exploit Nagumo\\u2019s indecision. They\\u2019re also handling explosives and flammable liquids in parts of the ship vulnerable to bomb blasts.\\n\\nFor all that
column60: the American air attacks were no masterpiece of massing firepower at the decisive place and time for mass impact. In mid-morning Hornet and Enterprise torpedo-bombers went in low

column76: \\u201cenough was enough.\\u201d He had the flagship signal to Enterprise dive-bomber squadrons circling overhead: \\u201cproceed on mission assigned.\\u201d In other words
column77: do not dawdle. Get aloft and proceed along your way. Spruance overrode procedures. column38: the dean of World War II naval historians
column39: Spruance displayed \\u201cthe very highest quality of tactical wisdom
column40: the power to seize opportunities.\\u201d And although Spruance was a surface-ship officer in charge of naval aviation assets
column41: he had the spine to overrule professional aviators when circumstances warranted.\\n\\nPacific Fleet boss Admiral Chester Nimitz afforded Spruance and Rear Admiral Frank Jack Fletcher\\u2014who headed up Task Force 17
column43: and was assigned overall tactical command\\u2014ample leeway to shape their high-seas fate. Nimitz instructed them to conduct themselves by \\u201cthe principle of calculated risk\\u201d at Midway. By that he meant avoiding \\u201cexposure of your force to attack by superior enemy forces without good prospect of inflicting . . . greater damage on the enemy.\\u201d\\n\\nHis directive made strategic sense. Both combatants had committed all of their deployable fleet carriers to action at Midway. The IJN enjoyed a 4-3 numerical edge
column44: yet it was Nimitz who had the luxury of risking his carriers. They were replaceable where Japan\\u2019s were not. Nimitz presided over a remnant of the prewar Pacific Fleet. He knew that a bigger
column45: better U.S. Navy\\u2014including a brand-new class of fleet carriers
column46: the Essex class\\u2014was building in shipyards back home and would make its way to the Pacific Ocean starting in 1943. With only a fraction of American industrial capacity
column47: Japan could scarcely regenerate naval strength depleted in action. America could redeem its losses and then some; Japan would struggle to sustain itself.\\n\\nIf you have a spare weapon in the armory\\u2014or soon will\\u2014you may as well risk the one you have.\\n\\nAdmiral Spruance wielded Task Force 16 to good effect. Around daybreak on June 4 a Midway-based patrol plane reported sighting two IJN carriers steaming southeast toward the island. The American fleet had taken station to Midway\\u2019s northeast in hopes of mounting an ambush from an unexpected quarter

Carrier crews trying to refuel and arm warplanes are busy with other duties than self-defense. They\\u2019re also handling explosives and flammable liquids in parts of the ship vulnerable to bomb blasts.\\n\\nFor all that
column60: the American air attacks were no masterpiece of massing firepower at the decisive place and time for mass impact. In mid-morning Hornet and Enterprise torpedo-bombers went in low
column61: and broke themselves against the curtain of IJN anti-aircraft fire as well as Zeke fighters swooping overhead. While Japanese defenders concentrated their energies down low

column65: struck back successfully at Yorktown\\u2014only to be dispatched itself late that afternoon.\\n\\nThe Imperial Japanese Navy thus lost four of the Kid\\u014d Butai\\u00ad\\u00ad\\u2019s four fleet carriers in a day (two others damaged previously remained at home under repair and would return to action later in the war)

column71: gather overhead
column72: and then proceed on their route en masse. In the process the first aircraft to launch would orbit overhead\\u2014and waste precious fuel while the rest of the group assembled.\\n\\nThe Hornet air wing conducted a deferred departure on the morning of June 4 at Browning\\u2019s direction. When the staff radio intelligence officer reported intercepting a Japanese scout plane\\u2019s transmission reporting the task force\\u2019s whereabouts
column76: \\u201cenough was enough.\\u201d He had the flagship signal to Enterprise dive-bomber squadrons circling overhead: \\u201cproceed on mission assigned.\\u201d In other words
column77: do not dawdle. Get aloft and proceed along your way. Spruance overrode procedures. That\\u2019s why the air wings attacked in fragmentary fashion\\u2014a drawback in combat\\u2014but it helped the bomber squadrons conserve fuel they would need to search out and attack the Japanese flattops. \\u201cIt was the right decision

column8: \"content\": \"Key Point: This battle changed it all.\\n\\nFounding German chancellor Otto von Bismarck was not a funny guy. As a rule
column9: in fact
column10: Bismarck was downright grim. He glowers at us from eternity. Once in awhile
column11: though
column12: the Iron Chancellor came out with a jest worthy of the great Yogi Berra\\u2014as when he reputedly proclaimed that Providence smiles on \\u201cfools
column13: drunkards
column14: and the United States of America.\\u201d Foolish besotted \\u2018Mercans must be triply blessed.\\n\\nYet Providence seldom does it all. It furnishes opportunity perchance. Individuals must grab and exploit opportunities fortune\\u2019s favor deigns to bestow on them.\\n\\nNever was this truer than June 1942
column15: when U.S. Navy and Imperial Japanese Navy (IJN) aircraft-carrier task forces met in battle off Midway Island
column16: an atoll northwest of Hawaii. Hollywood essays a rare look at naval history this weekend with the release of director Roland Emmerich\\u2019s Midway
column17: the first cinematic account of this epic clash since the 1970s. Not having seen the film yet
column18: I can neither praise its wholesome goodness nor damn its failings.\\n\\nThere remains plenty to say about the encounter
column19: regardless of how well Hollywood did its work. Fortune granted the USA its favor at Midway
column20: as Bismarck might have prophesied. But it was sound doctrine and strategy
column21: entrepreneurship among naval aviators
column22: and shrewd senior leadership that positioned the U.S. Pacific Fleet to harvest the opportunities placed before it. And harvest them the navy did. By the time the guns

column25: when Lord Horatio Nelson\\u2019s Royal Navy swept the combined French and Spanish fleets from the briny main at Trafalgar. Was it a \\u201cdecisive\\u201d victory as well as complete? Opinions vary. How to define that word commonly provokes one of those scholarly debates that\\u2019s so envenomed because the stakes are so small. Some scholars of martial affairs insist that a decisive battle must lead directly to peace in fairly short order. It must decide the outcome of the war as a whole in order to qualify.\\n\\nThat\\u2019s a mighty constricted definition. To its purveyors we might say
column26: with Coach Lee Corso\\u2014this being college football season\\u2014not so fast
column27: my friend! And hazard a contrary view
column28: as Corso does when picking winners and losers on game day.\\n\\nThe classics of strategy divulge no concrete definition. Carl von Clausewitz comes closest in On War
column29: stating vaguely that a great battle constitutes \\u201ca decisive factor in the outcome of a war or campaign\\u201d (my italics). column7: \"title\": \"What happens on Brexit day and what comes next?\"
column8: \"content\": \"There will be little official pageantry to mark Britain\\u2019s departure from the European Union at 11pm on Friday. A clock counting down the last hour will be projected on to No 10 Downing Street
column9: and Nigel Farage will host a celebration in Parliament Square where flagpoles will fly union jacks.\\n\\nBut there will be nothing like the torchlight procession that marked the august occasion on 1 January 1973 when the prime minister Edward Heath was joined in Brussels by his predecessors Harold Macmillan
column10: Alec Douglas-Home and a chorus of leaders from across the political divide to witness the accession of the UK into the European Economic Community.\\n\\nFriday will mark the start of what is likely to be an uphill battle to get a trade deal done by the end of the year
column11: not to mention all the non-trade issues that must also be resolved including security and intelligence cooperation
column12: fisheries
column13: data
column14: education and research collaboration.\\n\\nYes. Although everyday life will remain the same and the UK will remain in the single market and the customs union until the end of the year as part of transition arrangements
column15: the withdrawal agreement will be a legally binding international treaty. It carries sanctions for any \\u201cbacksliding or half measures\\u201d
column16: as Michel Barnier\\u2019s adviser Stefaan de Rynck pointed out last week in London.\\n\\nWhat happens next?\\n\\nWe know little of the plans for the negotiations
column17: and parliamentary scrutiny of Brexit has been restricted. The House of Lords EU committee has invited but failed to get Stephen Barclay to appear to explain the next stages
column18: sources say.\\n\\n\\u201cThe UK is five days away from entering into a highly complex and potentially extensive set of negotiations with the EU
column19: and from entering into quite an elaborate joint institutional architecture with the EU to manage the withdrawal agreement. But we know little in detail about how either of these are going to work on the UK side
column20: in terms of institutions and process
column21: \\u201d says Brigid Fowler
column22: a senior researcher with the Hansard Society.\\n\\nWhile business has been clamouring for the government to reveal its Brexit vision beyond the joint aspiration of a tariff-free
column24: little is known about Boris Johnson\\u2019s specific goals.\\n\\nHow will the PM lead the next phase?\\n\\nJohnson is doing everything he can to expunge the word Brexit from the British lexicon. He has already reduced parliamentary scrutiny of the next phase
column25: and his government has given only clues as to what the goals and red lines in negotiations will be.\\n\\nNegotiating mandates setting out wishlists and red lines are usually published by both sides before they enter into trade talks. Until Sunday
column26: when the Brexit secretary
column27: Stephen Barclay
column28: told the BBC\\u2019s Andrew Marr that they would be published
column29: it had not been clear that Johnson would do so at all.\\n\\nThe prime minister is expected to give further clues in a keynote speech in the next fortnight
column30: but parliament\\u2019s involvement in approving the negotiating mandate was removed from the Brexit bill.\\n\\n\\u201cEssentially
column31: the government seems to be planning to rely on normal mechanisms for ministerial accountability to parliament. These put the government in control of what information is made public and when
column32: \\u201d says Fowler.\\n\\nWhat about the cabinet reshuffle and Dominic Cummings\\u2019 mooted Whitehall bloodbath?\\n\\nA reshuffle is expected in early February and some departments are expected to be axed. Barclay\\u2019s Brexit department will close on Friday and there could be changes to the function of the Treasury
column33: the Department for International Trade
column34: the Foreign Office
column35: the Department for Business
column37: the Home Office and the Department for Environment
column38: Food and Rural Affairs.\\n\\nMichael Gove
column39: the chancellor of the duchy of Lancaster
column40: continues to head a special Exiting the EU operation committee
column41: known as XO
column42: and is expected to continue to have a key role in the next phase.\\n\\nHMRC will be one of the key cogs in the Brexit chain as work must start urgently on the complex arrangements for Northern Ireland that will affect all businesses trading on both sides of the Irish Sea. Expect an early clash between the EU and Johnson
column43: who has repeatedly claimed there will be no checks on goods
column44: in contradiction of the withdrawal agreement.\\n\\nNew border systems will be needed for the rest of the UK
column45: and the EU and HMRC will be frustrated in designing them until the shape of the deal is known
column46: possibly not until the summer. HMRC is short of key personnel and recently advertised for a deputy director to take charge of EU exit
column47: who \\u201cwill be responsible for providing the strategic direction for the project
column48: delivering all the operational
column49: communications and business changes needed in readiness for the UK\\u2019s exit.\\u201d\\n\\nA former head of HMRC has said it could take five years to get the sort of IT system proposed for Northern Ireland up and running.\\n\\nExpect plenty of sabre-rattling on both sides
column50: but negotiations are unlikely to begin before March. The European commission kicked off its 30-stage process in agreeing its negotiating goals before Christmas and these are expected to be signed off by member states at a meeting on 25 February.\\n\\nWho will be negotiating for the UK?\\n\\nDavid Frost
column51: who replaced Oliver Robbins as the chief negotiator
column52: is expected to lead a team of about 30 calling on expert knowledge from civil servants and trade experts. Some have suggested the government should hire as many as possible from the Canadian team that sealed Canada\\u2019s new deal with the EU.\\n\\nWhat about the joint committee?\\n\\nUnder the withdrawal agreement
column53: a joint committee of EU and UK representatives to oversee implementation of the treaty can sit from 1 February.\\n\\nWhile the powers of the committee are known
column54: we know very little else. The appointments process
column55: the size of the committee and how often it will meet has yet to be disclosed. One senior source said the committee would not be as influential as speculated.\\n\\nThis remains the single most contentious part of the Brexit deal because of the checks on goods crossing the Irish Sea. De Rynck said last week that the EU and the UK would have to be \\u201cvery disciplined\\u201d if they were to get a new system for trading in Northern Ireland ready for 31 December.\\n\\nBrussels and Irish political leaders are already alarmed by Johnson\\u2019s repeated declarations that there will be no checks on goods crossing the Irish Sea
column56: even though some of these will be mandatory.\\n\\nHelen McEntee
column57: Ireland\\u2019s minister for European affairs contradicted him directly on Sunday telling Sky News\\u2019s Sophy Ridge: \\u201cThere will be no checks on the island of Ireland
column58: we\\u2019ve been very clear on this.\\u201d\\n\\nUnderneath the joint committee will be a specialised committee and working advisory group to establish the Northern Ireland protocol.\\n\\nNorthern Ireland businesses have urged the government to set up the working group urgently so that the detail of the checks can be determined quickly.\"
